DT Article
TI Four new species of Desmopachria Babington (Insecta, Coleoptera,
   Dytiscidae) from the Amazon river floodplain.
AU Braga, Rafael Benzi (rafaelbenzi@gmail.com) 
   Ferreira-Jr, Nelson
SO Zootaxa
VL 2415
PS 33-42
PD 31 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2415.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02415p042.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Desmopachria from the Amazon river floodplain
   (varzea) are described and illustrated, D. manus sp. nov., D. varzeana
   sp. nov., D. cavia sp. nov. and D. nigrocapitata sp. nov., together with
   new distributional records of D. balionata Miller, D. draco Miller, D.
   subnotata Sharp and D. striola Zimmermann for Amazonas and Para states
   in Brazil.
C1 Braga, Rafael Benzi; Programa de Pos-graduacao em Ciencias Biologicas -
   Zoologia, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Caixa
   Postal 68044, 21941-971 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil, Brazil.
EM rafaelbenzi@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   South America
DE Desmopachria balionata; Desmopachria draco; Desmopachria striola;
   Desmopachria subnotata [Brazil / Amazonas & Para / New record]. 
   Desmopachria cavia; Desmopachria manus; Desmopachria nigrocapitata;
   Desmopachria varzeana [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Dytiscidae

   Desmopachria cavia (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 37]. 
   Desmopachria draco (Dytiscidae): [New record]. 
   Desmopachria manus (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 34]. 
   Desmopachria nigrocapitata (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 38]. 
   Desmopachria striola (Dytiscidae): [New record]. 
   Desmopachria subnotata (Dytiscidae): [New record]. 
   Desmopachria varzeana (Dytiscidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 36].

DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Japananus Ball, 1931 (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae).
AU Xing, Ji-Chun (lizizhong38@163.com) 
   Dai, Ren-Huai
   Li, Zi-Zhong
SO Zootaxa
VL 2415
PS 63-68
PD 31 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2415.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02415p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Japananus Ball from China are described and
   illustrated: J. meilingensis sp. nov. and J. lamellosus sp. nov.. A key
   is given to distinguish all species of the genus. The type specimens of
   the new species are deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou
   University, Guiyang, China (GUGC).
C1 Xing, Ji-Chun; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University, The
   Provincial Key Laboratory for Agricultural Pest Management of
   Mountainous Region, Guiyang, Guizhou 550025, China, China.
EM lizizhong38@163.com
SC Zoology

   Japananus meilingensis [Jiangxi /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,

OR Japananus - Ball 1931 (Cicadellidae): [Key to species, Males, p. 64]. 
   Japananus lamellosus (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Guizhou, P. 66]. 
   Japananus meilingensis (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Jiangxi, P. 65].

PT J
AN ZOOR14609062382
DT Article
TI Contribution on the identity of Cricula pelengensis Paukstadt &
   Paukstadt, 2009 and further taxa of the genus Cricula Walker, 1855
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Beitrag zur Identitaet von Cricula pelengensis Paukstadt & Paukstadt,
   2009 and weiterer Taxa der Gattung Cricula Walker, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Paukstadt, Ulrich (ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de) 
   Paukstadt, Laela H.
SO Beitraege zur Kenntnis der Wilden Seidenspinner
VL 8
IS 2
PS 55-64
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent publications on new taxa of the genus Cricula WALKER, 1855 of the
   family Saturniidae BOISDUVAL, 1837 ("1834") (Lepidoptera) by Paukstadt &
   Paukstadt (2009), Naumann & Loffler (2010), and Brechlin (2010) are
   evaluated herein. C. hayatiae PAUKSTADT & SUHARDJONO, 1992 was tentative
   and preliminary placed into the elaezia-group (sensu Nassig 1995) by
   Paukstadt & Paukstadt (2009) mainly due to morphological reasons.
   Naumann & Loffler (2010) excluded hayatiae together with the new
   described maxalorensis NAUMANN & LOFFLER, 2010 from the
   trifenestrata-group (sensu Nassig 1995) based on DNA barcoding but the
   authors not proposed a new group-name for this taxon. The authors noted
   that both taxa are more allied with luzonica JORDAN, 1909. As already
   proposed by Nassig (1995) we place the taxon hayatiae now back into the
   trifenestrata-group (sensu Nassig 1995) based on the morphology. The
   taxon hayatiae most probably represents a very early off-spring within
   the taxa of the trifenestrata-group (sensu Nassig 1995) and shows
   typical characteristics of the trifenestrata-group and the elaezia-group
   (both sensu Nassig 1995) as well. We do not intend to separate hayatiae
   from the trifenestratagroup (sensu Nassig 1995). When separating
   hayatiae from the trifenestrata-group (sensu Nassig 1995) some further
   major changes in the group status of other taxa in this and other
   species-groups are needed. This can lead to an unnecessary "atomization"
   of species-groups in Cricula. The recent description of pelengensis
   PAUKSTADT & PAUKSTADT (2009) obviously was based on a mislabeled
   specimen purchased by the senior author from a local dealer on the
   island of Bali. The male singleton was received together with a large
   series of C. trifenestrata banggaiensis NAUMANN & PAUKSTADT, 1997 from
   Pulau Peleng, Banggai Archipelago. In the original description the
   singleton was compared with specimens of the elaezia-group (sensu Nassig
   1995) from Sulawesi, Java, Sumatra, Borneo, and the Malay Peninsula.
   Unfortunately no specimens from the island of Bali were available for
   comparisons. Naumann & Loffler (2010) noted that the origin of
   pelengensis remains doubtful. DNA barcoding now confirms that
   pelengensis is conspecific with the populations of the elaezia-group
   (sensu Nassig 1995) from Bali. Therefore baliensis NAUMANN & LOFFLER,
   2010 syn. nov., is considered to be a junior subjective synonym of
   pelengensis PAUKSTADT & PAUKSTADT, 2009. The range of pelengensis
   remains unknown. Presently we assume that pelengensis is distributed on
   the island of Bali and in the arid regions of the East and Central Java
   Provinces. This idea is weakly supported by DNA Barcoding. During our
   studies on the Indonesian wild silkmoths and in particular during the
   preparation of the manuscript on pelengensis the authors did learn that
   the islands of Java, Sumatra, and Borneo, as well as the Malay Peninsula
   are occupied by distinct taxa of the elaezia-group (sensu Nassig 1995)
   which were so far mentioned in literature under the name of elaezia
   JORDAN, 1909. C. elaezia was originally described from West Java. After
   we had received the official information from Dr. R. Brechlin (pers.
   comm.) that he intends to describe new taxa of the elaezia-group (sensu
   Nassig 1995) from Southeast Asia our descriptions in preparation were
   cancelled. Unfortunately the taxa in question were after that described
   and published almost simultaneously by Brechlin (2010a), Naumann &
   Loffler (2010) followed by Brechlin (2010b). Therefore separata NAUMANN
   & LOFFLER, 2010 syn. nov., is considered to be a junior subjective
   synonym of elaeziosumatrana BRECHLIN, 2010 stat. rev. and
   magnifenestrata NAUMANN & LOFFLER, 2010 syn. nov., is considered to be a
   junior subjective synonym of C. elaeziobornea BRECHLIN, 2010 stat. rev.
   C. magnifenestrata was described from Sabah, East Malaysia (holotype),
   the Central Kalimantan Province, and the mountain range of Peninsular
   Malaysia. Naumann & Loffler (2010) remarked that the populations from
   Peninsular Malaysia and Borneo could be separated on subspecific niveau
   but this was not intent to do by the authors. The taxon
   elaeziopahangensis BRECHLIN, 2010 stat. rev. was originally described
   from the Cameron Highlands, Pahang, West Malaysia (holotype). This taxon
   was lowered into synonymy with magnifenestrata by Naumann (2010). We
   herewith remove elaeziopahangensis BRECHLIN, 2010 stat. rev. from
   synonymy with magnifenestrata NAUMANN & LOFFLER, 2010 syn. nov. Due to
   zoogeographic reasons and as a result of our studies we downgrade
   elaeziopahangensis BRECHLIN, 2010 to elaeziobornea elaeziopahangensis
   BRECHLIN, 2010, stat. nov. Further studies need to clarify whether
   elaeziopahangensis can be upgraded to species rank.
C1 Paukstadt, Ulrich; Knud-Rasmussen-Strasse 5, 26389 Wilhelmshaven,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1612-2674
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Cricula [Asia / South east Asia / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Cricula - Walker 1855 (Saturniidae). 
   Cricula elaeziobornea - Brechlin 2010 (Saturniidae): [Syn nov, Cricula
   magnifenestrata Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 57; Removal from synonymy,
   With Cricula magnifenestrata Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 56]. 
   Cricula elaeziobornea elaeziopahangensis - Brechlin 2010 (Saturniidae):
   [Downgraded from, Cricula elaeziopahangensis, p. 57]. 
   Cricula elaeziopahangensis - Brechlin 2010 (Saturniidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Cricula magnifenestrata Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 57;
   Downgraded to, Cricula elaeziobornea elaeziopahangensis, p. 57]. 
   Cricula elaeziosumatrana - Brechlin 2010 (Saturniidae): [Syn nov,
   Cricula separata Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 56; Removal from synonymy,
   With Cricula separata Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 56]. 
   Cricula magnifenestrata - Naumann & Loeffler 2010 (Saturniidae):
   [Removal from synonymy, Cricula elaeziobornea Brechlin 2010, p. 56;
   Removal from synonymy, Cricula elaeziopahangensis Brechlin 2010, p. 57].
   
   Cricula pelengensis - Paukstadt & Paukstadt 2009 (Saturniidae): [Syn
   nov, Cricula baliensis Naumann & Loeffler 2010, p. 56]. 
   Cricula separata - Naumann & Loeffler 2010 (Saturniidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Cricula elaeziosumatrana Brechlin 2010, p. 56]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14609062382
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Antheraea (Antheraea) ranongensis sp. nov., a new wild silkmoth from
   Thailand (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Antheraea (Antheraea) ranongensis sp. nov., eine neue Saturniide von
   Thailand (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Paukstadt, Ulrich (ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de) 
   Paukstadt, Laela H.
SO Beitraege zur Kenntnis der Wilden Seidenspinner
VL 8
IS 2
PS 65-74
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new wild silkmoth (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) from southern Thailand is
   described herein: Antheraea (Antheraea) ranongensis sp. nov. Thus far
   this new taxon is only known in a male singleton. The specimen was
   supposed to be a variation of one of the taxa of the frithi-complex of
   Southeast Asia but DNA barcoding within the BOLD project (Canadian
   Centre for DNA Barcoding, Biodiversity Institute of Ontario, University
   of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, Canada) not confirms our presumption. DNA
   barcoding does not fully match with any other sampled taxon of the
   frithi-subgroup (sensu Nassig 1995) from Southeast Asia. A. (A.)
   ranongensis sp. nov. is a taxon of the frithi-subgroup (sensu Nassig
   1991) of the mylitta/frithi-group (sensu Paukstadt, Brosch & Paukstadt
   1999) of the subgenus Antheraea HUEBNER, 1819 ("1816"). With a forewing
   length of only 55 mm, the singleton represents one of the smallest
   specimens / species in the frithi-subgroup (sensu L. H. & U. Paukstadt
   2003). A. (A.) ranongensis sp. nov. can be easy distinguished from other
   taxa in this complex by the small size, large ocelli with large hyaline
   center, short forewing apices, and small antennae. A. (A.)
   angustomarginata BRECHLIN & MEISTER, 2009 from Cambodia most probably is
   the nearest relative of A. (A.) ranongensis sp. nov. but clearly
   distinct in male genitalia morphology and the DNA barcode. The
   appropriate female adult and the preimaginal instars of A. (A.)
   ranongensis sp. nov. remain unknown thus far.
C1 Paukstadt, Ulrich; Knud-Rasmussen-Strasse 5, 26389 Wilhelmshaven,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1612-2674
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Antheraea (Antheraea) ranongensis [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Antheraea (Antheraea) ranongensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P.
   69].

DT Article
TI Cricula trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov., a new wild silkmoth
   from Halmahera, Moluccas, Indonesia (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Cricula trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov., eine neue Saturniide
   von Halmahera, Molukken, Indonesien (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Paukstadt, Ulrich (ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de) 
   Paukstadt, Laela H.
SO Beitraege zur Kenntnis der Wilden Seidenspinner
VL 8
IS 2
PS 89-100
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new subspecies of the genus Cricula WALKER, 1855 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) is described from the Island of Halmahera, North Moluccas
   Province, Indonesia: Cricula trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov.
   Etymology: C. trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov. is named after
   the collecting site, the island of Halmahera in the North Moluccas
   Province, Indonesia. C. trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov. is a
   taxon of the trifenestrata-group (sensu Nassig 1995). Thus far this
   subspecies is only known from the island of Halmahera. Therefore the
   taxon is considered to be endemic to this island, as most of the other
   taxa of the family Saturniidae BOISDUVAL, 1837 ("1834"), too. C.
   trifenestrata (HELFER, 1837) is a widespread species which ranges from
   India to China and via the continental islands of the Sunda Shelf to the
   Philippines, the Eastern Lesser Sunda Islands and the Moluccas. Within
   the range of trifenestrata many subspecies were described. Although the
   new subspecies is well isolated on the island of Halmahera, we will
   treat this populations in subspecific rank following Nassig (1989) and
   many other authors. Nothing is known on the ecology and the biology of
   this subspecies. The preimaginal instars remain unknown thus far. Due to
   the fact that no [male] adults from the island of Halmahera were
   available in the beginning of our studies, we intend to describe the new
   subspecies after the [female] adult. Only very recently a [male] abdomen
   for dissection and color pictures of a [male] adult were received from
   Dr. W. A. Naessig, Senckenberg Museum Frankfurt Lepidoptera / SMFL
   (Frankfurt am Main) for our studies. The [female] singleton was found to
   be slightly distinct from those of trifenestrata kransi JURRIAANSE &
   LINDEMANS, 1920 (Sulawesi), trifenestrata serama NAESSIG, 1989 (Seram),
   trifenestrata banggaiensis NAUMANN & PAUKSTADT, 1997 (Banggai
   Archipelago), and trifenestrata javana WATSON, 1913 (Java), which are
   obviously the nearest relatives within this group. Due to a mainly
   Papuan-Australian fauna of Halmahera we assume that halmaheraensis
   subsp. nov. was introduced some time ago by wind or human, eventually
   together with the hosts of the caterpillars of Cricula. Besides small
   differences in the [female]antennal morphologies, genitalia structures
   and the habitus to other related taxa, the description based on the
   particular zoogeography in the Moluccas, too. The [male] and [female]
   adults of C. trifenestrata halmaheraensis subsp. nov. and the [male] and
   [female] genitalia structures are illustrated herein.
C1 Paukstadt, Ulrich; Knud-Rasmussen-Strasse 5, 26389 Wilhelmshaven,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ulrich.paukstadt@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1612-2674
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cricula trifenestrata halmaheraensis [Indonesia /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Cricula trifenestrata halmaheraensis (Saturniidae): [Subsp nov,
   Indonesia, P. 94].

DT Article
TI Edrioasteroidea from the Seifen-Schichten in the Westerwald, Rhenish
   Slate Mountains (Lower Devonian, Germany), part 1.
FT Edrioacteroidea aus den Seifen-Schichten im Westerwald, Rheinisches
   Schiefer-Gebirge (Unter-Devon, Deutschland), Teil 1.
AU Mueller, Peter (Mueller-lgh@t-online.de) 
   Hahn, Gerhard
SO Geologica et Palaeontologica
VL 43
PS 9-47
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new rich edrioasteroid fauna is made known from the Seifen-Schichten
   (Siegenian, Lower Devonian) of the Westerwald (Holzbach Valley near
   Niederahren). In this first part of the publication the following taxa
   are treated: Pyrgocystis? postpetalus n. sp., Eopostibulla pustulata n.
   gen. n. sp., Agelacrinites thor n. sp., Krama hispanica n. sp., K.
   germanica n. sp., K. odin n. sp. and Parakrama grebelae n. gen. n. sp.
   The morphology of these species is decribed, their relationships are
   discussed, all important specimens are figured.

PT J
AN ZOOR14902010719
DT Article
TI Bivalves from the Carboniferous glacial deposits of central Patagonia,
   Argentina.
AU Gonzalez, Carlos R. (crgonzalez@csnat.unt.edu.ar) 
SO Geologica et Palaeontologica
VL 43
PS 61-81
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Carboniferous deposits of central Patagonia afford important evidence on
   the range and origin of various components of the endemic bivalve fauna
   of Gondwana, but the available material of some interesting forms is
   unfortunately scarce and incomplete remains that allow a very limited
   description. A new genus, Waterhouseus, and four new species are
   described: Waterhouseus keideli n. sp., Streblopteria? n. sp.,
   Megadesmus? n. sp. and Myonia? prinsi n. sp. The morphology of
   Merismopteria salinensis GoNZALEz is amplified after revision. New
   occurrences are reported for two previously known species: Waterhouseus
   tepuelensis (GONZALEZ, 1969) and Pyramus primigenius GONZALEZ, 1972.
   Five further species: Nuculopsis sp., Leptodesma (Leiopteria) sp.,
   Myonia? sp. Pyramus? sp. and Amosius sp. are left innominate because
   insufficiently known.
C1 Gonzalez, Carlos R.; Fundacion Miguel Lillo, Miguel Lillo 251, 4000
   Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
EM crgonzalez@csnat.unt.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 0072-1018
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Bivalvia [Zoogeography / Palaeozoogeography / Systematics] [Argentina /
   Patagonia, central / stratigraphical distribution] [Carboniferous /  /
   ]. 
   Myonia? prinsi; Waterhouseus keideli [Argentina /  / new species]
   [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
   Waterhouseus [Carboniferous /  / New genus].

PT J

DT Article
TI [Trilobite records from the Lower Carboniferous in the Hut Valley (Upper
   Harz, Germany).]
FT Trilobiten-Funde aus dem Unter-Karbon im Hut-Tal (Ober-Harz,
   Duetschland).
AU Mueller, Peter (Mueller-Lgh@t-online.de) 
   Brauckmann, Carsten
SO Geologica et Palaeontologica
VL 43
PS 83-91
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two trilobite specimens from the Early Carboniferous (= Mississippian)
   sequence of the "Hut-Tat" SE of Clausthal-Zellerfeld in the Upper Harz
   Mountains (Lower Saxony, Germany) are described. One of them can be
   determined as Archegonus (Phillibole) cf. hombergensis HAHN, HAHN &
   MUELLER, 2007; it enables to restrict the age of this part of the
   section approximately to the ammonoid zone of Entogonites nasutus (Herm.
   SCHMIDT, 1941) (= cu [delta]) and thus to the early
   Bevrichoceras-Entogonites genozone of the late Middle / early Upper
   Visean. The other specimen is a well-preserved cranidium; it represents
   a new species of Chlupacula (Pseudodrevermannia n. sg.): Chlupacula
   (Pseudodrevermannia n. sg.) adinolis n. sp.
C1 Mueller, Peter; Waldstrasse 8, D-56459 Langenhahn, Germany, Germany.
EM Mueller-Lgh@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0072-1018
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic

   Mountains, Hut-Tal / new record; systematics; stratigraphic
   significance] [Carboniferous / Mississippian / ]. 
   Chlupacula (Pseudodrevermannia) [Carboniferous /  / New subgenus]. 
   Chlupacula (Pseudodrevermannia) adinois [Germany /  / new species]
   [Carboniferous /  / ].

   record].

   Drevermannia pruvosti Richter & Richter 1939, p. 86, Carboniferous;
   Fossil]. 
   Chlupacula (Pseudodrevermannia) adinois (Trilobita): [Sp nov, Germany,
   Carboniferous, P. 87; Fossil]. 
   Chlupacula (Pseudodrevermannia) pruvosti - (Richter & Richter 1939)
   (Trilobita): [Comb nov, Transferred from Drevermannia, p. 86; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14902010721
DT Article
TI Upper Pennsylvanian non-marine bivalves of western Argentina.
AU Diaz Saravia, Pamela
   Gonzalez, Carlos R.
SO Geologica et Palaeontologica
VL 43
PS 93-102
PD 30 Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A non-marine bivalve fauna from the Upper Pennsylvanian deposits of
   western Argentina is described. This fauna shows very poor diversity:
   only the genus Anthraconaia is present with three new species:
   Anthraconaia polanskii n. sp., Anthraconaia subquadrata n. sp., and
   Anthraconaia? n. sp. The characteristics of the environment where these
   bivalves occur, show some resemblances with those prevailing in the
   Upper Pennsylvanian coal basins of Europe, suggesting that during that
   period climatic conditions in western Argentina were probably alike
   those of the palaeo-equatorial realm, and that a sort of link may have
   existed with that region.
C1 Diaz Saravia, Pamela; Fundacion M. Lillo, Miguel Lillo 251, 4000
   Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0072-1018
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Anthraconaia [Ecology / Palaeoecology / systematics] [Fossil assemblages
   /  / ] [Environmental indicators /  / ] [Argentina / San Juan, Colanguil
   Cordillera / ] [Carboniferous / Upper Pennsylvanian / ]. 
   Anthraconaia polanskii; Anthraconaia subquadrata [Argentina /  / new
   species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Pteriomorphia, Pterioida, Ambonychioidea
OR Anthraconaia - Trueman & Weir 1946 (Ambonychioidea): [Fossil]. 
   Anthraconaia polanskii (Ambonychioidea): [Sp nov, Argentina,
   Carboniferous, P. 98; Fossil]. 
   Anthraconaia subquadrata (Ambonychioidea): [Sp nov, Argentina,
   Carboniferous, P. 99; Fossil].

PS 67-72
PD Mar 30 2010

LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Barbiellinia (Diptera, Stratiomyidae) from Rio de
   Janeiro, Brazil. The genus Barbiellinia Bezzi, 1922, with five species,
   is endemic from Brazil. Here we described a new species Barbiellinia
   illaetabilis sp. nov. based on 26 specimens (25 males and 1 female) from
   the State of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

TI A review of the genus Macrocheilus Hope (Coleoptera: Carabidae:
   Helluonini) of China, with descriptions of seven new species.
AU Zhao, Danyang
   Tian, Mingyi (mytian@scau.edu.cn) 
SO Polish Journal of Entomology
VL 79
IS 1
PS 3-23
PD 30 March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper a review of the genus Macrocheilus Hope, 1838
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Helluonini) of China is provided, with
   descriptions of seven new species, viz. M. parvimaculatus sp. nov., M.
   gigas sp. nov., M. fuscipennis sp. nov., M. solidipalpis sp. nov., M.
   cheni sp. nov., M. quadratus sp. nov., and M. sinuatilabris sp. nov.. A
   key to all species found in China is also given. In addition, M.
   asteriscus White is reported from Laos, Indonesia and India for the
   first time.

TI Microlepidoptera of Hong Kong: taxonomic study on the genus Dichomeris
   Huebner, 1818, with descriptions of three new species (Lepidoptera:
   Gelechiidae).
AU Li, H.H. (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
   Zhen, H.
   Kendrick, R.C.
   Sterling, M.J.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 38
IS 149
PS 67-89
PD 30 de marzo 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This paper reports 19 species of the genus Dichomeris Hubner, 1818 from
   Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China. Three new species are
   described: Dichomeris argentenigera Li, Zhen & Kendrick. sp. n., D.
   hamulifera Li, Zhen & Kendrick. sp. n. and D. parvisexafurca Li, Zhen &
   Kendrick. sp. n.: two species are reported for the first time from
   China: D. sandycitis (Meyrick) and D. moriutii Ponomarenko & Ueda. The
   males of D. simaoensi Li & Wang and D. zonata Li & Wang as well as the
   female of D. sandycitis (Meyrick) are newly described. Images of adults,
   illustrations of genitalia of the new species and the newly described
   males and female are provided. A key for identifying the known species
   of Dichomeris in Hong Kong is given.

DT Article
TI A new Rhanidopsis West, 1930 from the Malay Peninsula (Lepidoptera:
   Geometridae, Geometrinae).
AU Viidalepp, J. (jaan.viidalepp@emu.ee) 
   Lindt, A.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 38
IS 149
PS 97-106
PD 30 de marzo 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new moth species from the oriental geometrid genus Rhanidopsis West,
   1930 is described: P. kogeri Viidalepp & Lindt, sp. n., from Cameron
   Highlands, Peninsular Malaysia is added to the distribution area of the
   genus, formerly known from the Philippines and Borneo. Phenotypical
   similarity of the genus with Afrotropical Dargeia Herbulot, 1977 and
   Neotropical Pyrochlora Warren, 1895 is discussed. Sonic plesiomorphic
   characters of Neotropical and Indoaustralian genera of Nemoriini are
   compared.
C1 Viidalepp, J.; Estonian Univ Life Sci, Inst Agron & Environm Studies,
   Riia St 181, Tartu, Estonia, Estonia.

FT Gentiliana Olivares & Angulo gen. n., para la fauna altoandina
   (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae, Cuculliinae).
AU Olivares, T.S. (tolivare@udec.cl) 
   Angulo, A.O.
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 38
IS 149
PS 115-119
PD 30 de marzo 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus Gentiliana Olivares & Angulo, gen. n., of the noctuidan
   subfamily Cucullinae is described. The new genus is present from the VII
   to X Chilean regions. The material studied belongs to the "Instituto y
   Fundacion Miguel Lillo (IFML)", Argentina and the type material is
   deposited in the Scientific Collection of Universidad de Concepcion
   (UCCC), Chile. The new genus differs from Argyrana Kohler, (1952) 1951
   in presenting an irregulary dentate ampulla, finishing in a point; a
   suboval to subquadrangular saccus; beside, the aedeagus cornuti does not
   have large spines.
C1 Olivares, T.S.; Concepcion Univ, Fac Ciencias Nat & Oceanog, Casilla
   160-C, Concepcion, Chile, Chile.
EM tolivare@udec.cl
SC Zoology

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position

TI New additional data on the life history of Euchloe belemia hesperidum
   Rothschild, 1913 and Euchloe belemia grancanariensis Acosta, 2008 are
   provided and a new synonym for the latter taxon is proposed
   (Lepidoptera: Pieridae).
FT Nuevas aportaciones al conocimiento del ciclo biologico de Euchloe
   belemia hesperidum Rothschild, 1913 y Euchloe belemia grancanariensis
   Acosta, 2008 y nueva sinonimia para este taxon (Lepidoptera: Pieridae).
AU Acosta-Fernandez, B. (benedictoacosta@gmail.com) 
SO SHILAP Revista de Lepidopterologia
VL 38
IS 149
PS 121-128
PD 30 de marzo 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Known information about the life of E. belemia hesperidum Rothschild,
   1913 and E. belemia grancanariensis Acosta, 2008 is expanded. The
   preimaginal stages are compared and several pictures of their
   caterpillars and pupae are provided. The first Hymenoptera parasitoids
   recorded for Euchloe belemia grancanariensis Acosta. 2008 are detailed:
   Cotesia glomerata (Linnaeus, 1758) and Microplitis sp. (Braconidae:
   Microgastrinae). Finally, Euchloe belemia grancanariensis Acosta, 2008 =
   Euchloe constantini Back, 2008 syn. n., is proposed.

AN ZOOR14605038227
DT Article
TI The first pararchaeid spider (Araneae: Pararchaeidae) from New
   Caledonia, with a discussion on spinneret spigots and egg sac morphology
   in Ozarchaea.
AU Rix, Michael G. (michael.rix@museum.wa.gov.au) 
   Harvey, Mark S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2414
PS 27-40
PD 30 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2414.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02414p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The first pararchaeid species to be recorded from outside Australia or
   New Zealand, Flavarchaea humboldti n. sp., is described from female
   specimens collected near the summit of Mont Humboldt, New Caledonia.
   Morphological and behavioural data are further described for Western
   Australian species of Ozarchaea Rix, with the spinneret spigot
   morphology of O. harveyi Rix imaged under a scanning electron
   microscope, and the egg sac of O. westraliensis Rix described for the
   first time. Pararchaeid spinnerets possess two major ampullate gland
   spigots on the anterior lateral spinnerets and no triad on the posterior
   lateral spinnerets; such a spinneret spigot arrangement does not support
   the placement of the Pararchaeidae in the superfamily Araneoidea, and
   further research is needed to test the phylogenetic position of this
   enigmatic family.
C1 Rix, Michael G.; Department of Terrestrial Zoology, Western Australian
   Museum, Locked Bag 49, Welshpool DC, Perth, Western Australia 6986,
   Australia.
EM michael.rix@museum.wa.gov.au
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Appendages;
   Reproduction; Land zones; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Flavarchaea humboldti [New Caledonia /  / New species]. 
   Ozarchaea harveyi [Spinnerets / Spinneret anatomy / ]. 
   Ozarchaea westraliensis [Egg / Egg sac morphology / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Flavarchaea humboldti (Araneae): [Sp nov, New Caledonia, P. 27]. 
   Ozarchaea harveyi (Araneae). 
   Ozarchaea westraliensis (Araneae).

TI A new species of freshwater crab of the genus Odontothelphusa Rodriguez,
   1982, (Crustacea: Decapoda: Pseudothelphusidae) from Chiapas, Mexico.
AU Villalobos, Jose Luis (hiriart@servidor.unam.mx) 
   Garcia, Anelli J.
   Velazquez, Ernesto
SO Zootaxa
VL 2414
PS 52-58
PD 30 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2414.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02414p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of freshwater crab of the genus Odontothelphusa is
   described. The specimens were collected from one tributary of the
   Malpaso Dam in northwestern Chiapas state, extending the geographical
   distribution of the genus to southwestern Mexico. The new species
   differs from its congeners by the presence of a basal rounded tubercle
   and a small acute spine near the pointed end of the strong proximomesial
   spine. The new species represents the seventh species in the genus.
C1 Villalobos, Jose Luis; Coleccion Nacional de Crustaceos, Instituto de
   Biologa, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Apartado Postal
   70-153, Mexico 04510, D.F., Mexico, Mexico.

DT Article
TI A basal parvicursorine (Theropoda: Alvarezsauridae) from the Upper
   Cretaceous of China.
AU Xu, Xing
   Wang, De-You
   Sullivan, Corwin
   Hone, David W.E.
   Han, Feng-Lu
   Yan, Rong-Hao
   Du, Fu-Ming
SO Zootaxa
VL 2413
PS 1-19
PD 29 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2413.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02413p019.pdf
LA English
U1 1
U2 7
AB A new alvarezsaurid theropod, Xixianykus zhangi gen. et sp. nov., is
   described based on a partial postcranial skeleton collected from the
   Upper Cretaceous Majiacun Formation of Xixia County, Henan Province. The
   new taxon can be diagnosed by the following autapomorphies: sacral
   rib-transverse process complexes and zygapophyses fused to form separate
   anterior and posterior laminae; distinct fossa dorsal to antitrochanter
   on lateral surface of ilium; short ridge along posterior surface of
   pubic shaft near proximal end; distinct depression on lateral surface of
   ischium near proximal end; sharp groove along posterior surface of
   ischium; distal end of femur with transversely narrow ectocondylar tuber
   that extends considerable distance proximally as sharp ridge;
   transversely narrow tibial cnemial crest with sharp, ridgelike distal
   half; lateral margin of tibiotarsus forms step near distal end; fibula
   with substantial extension of proximal articular surface onto posterior
   face of posteriorly curving shaft; distal tarsals and metatarsals
   co-ossified to form tarsometatarsus; and sharp flange along anteromedial
   margin of metatarsal IV near proximal end. Cladistic analysis places
   this taxon as a basal parvicursorine within the Alvarezsauridae, a
   position consistent with the presence of several incipiently developed
   parvicursorine features in this taxon and also with its relatively early
   geological age. A brief analysis of vertebral functional morphology,
   together with data from the hindlimb, suggests that parvicursorines
   represent extreme cursors among non-avian dinosaurs.
C1 Xu, Xing; Key Laboratory of Evolutionary Systematics of Vertebrates,
   Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology & Paleoanthropology, Chinese
   Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100044, China, China.
RI Benton, Michael J/A-5639-2008
OI Benton, Michael J/0000-0002-4323-1824; Sullivan,
   Corwin/0000-0002-5488-6797
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Xixianykus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Xixianykus zhangi [Henan /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Theropoda
OR Xixianykus (Theropoda): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Parvicursorinae, Type
   species Xixianykus zhangi, p. 2, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Xixianykus zhangi (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Henan, P. 2; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14607047630
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14607047631
DT Article
TI A third new Cyrtodactylus (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from Phong Nha-Ke Bang
   National Park, Truong Son Range, Vietnam.
AU Ziegler, Thomas (ziegler@koelnerzoo.de) 
   Nazarov, Roman
   Orlov, Nikolai
   Nguyen, Truong Quang
   Vu, Thanh Ngoc
   Dang, Kien Ngoc
   Dinh, Tri Huy
   Schmitz, Andreas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2413
PS 20-36
PD 29 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2413.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02413p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB We describe a third cryptic species of the genus Cyrtodactylus from
   Phong Nha - Ke Bang National Park, Quang Binh Province, Vietnam.
   Cyrtodactylus roesleri sp. nov. is distinguished from the remaining
   Indochinese bent-toed geckos by a combination of the following
   characters: size small, with a maximum SVL of 75.3 mm; dorsal pattern
   consisting of dark nuchal band and 4-5 sometimes irregularly shaped dark
   transversal bands between limbs; ventrals in 34-40 longitudinal rows at
   midbody; continuous series of 20-28 precloacal and femoral pores in
   males; subcaudal scales transversally enlarged. It is the 15th new
   reptilian taxon described as new from the karst forests of Phong Nha -
   Ke Bang National Park in the past decade. In addition, it is the 19th
   species of Cyrtodactylus known from Vietnam and the third Cyrtodactylus
   occurring in sympatry in the karst forests of Phong Nha - Ke Bang
   National Park.
C1 Ziegler, Thomas; Cologne Zoo, Riehler Strasse 173, D-50735, Cologne,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ziegler@koelnerzoo.de
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyrtodactylus [Vietnam /  / Key to species]. 
   Cyrtodactylus roesleri [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus (Gekkonidae): [Key to species, Vietnam, P. 33]. 
   Cyrtodactylus cryptus (Gekkonidae): [Diagnostic characters, P. 32]. 
   Cyrtodactylus phongnhakebangensis (Gekkonidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 32]. 
   Cyrtodactylus roesleri (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 24].

DT Article
TI A new dendrobatid frog (Anura: Dendrobatidae: Anomaloglossus) from the
   Orinoquian rainforest, southern Venezuela.
AU Barrio-Amoros, Cesar L. (cesarlba@yahoo.com) 
   Santos, Juan Carlos
   Jovanovic, Olga
SO Zootaxa
VL 2413
PS 37-50
PD 29 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2413.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/2/zt02413p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of Anomaloglossus is described from the Venezuelan
   Guayana; it is the 21st described species of Anomaloglossus from the
   Guiana Shield, and the 15th from Venezuela. This species inhabits
   rainforest on granitic substrate on the northwestern edge of the Guiana
   Shield (Estado Amazonas, Venezuela). The new species is distinguished
   from congeners by sexual dimorphism, its unique male color pattern
   (including two bright orange parotoid marks and two orange paracloacal
   spots on dark brown background), call characteristics and other
   morphological features. Though to the new species is known only from the
   northwestern edge of the Guiana Shield, its distribution may be more
   extensive, as there are no significant biogeographic barriers isolating
   the type locality from the granitic lowlands of Venezuela.
C1 Barrio-Amoros, Cesar L.; Fundacion AndigenA, Apartado postal 210, 5101-A
   Merida, Venezuela, Venezuela.

AB Eulimnadia graniticola n. sp. from Stone Mountain, Georgia, and the
   Florida Keys, USA, is defined primarily on molecular characters and egg
   morphology. Ecological, reproductive and life history data are provided.
   This species is the second species of branchiopod crustacean reported
   from Stone Mountain more closely related to the South American fauna
   than to its North American congeners.

DT Article
TI Cryptotendipes Lenz from Manitoba, Canada, with keys to known immatures
   of the genus (Diptera: Chironomidae).
AU Saether, Ole A. (ole.sather@zmb.uib.no) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2412
PS 1-20
PD 29 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2412.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02412p020.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Cryptotendipes tuberosus sp. n. from Southern Indian Lake, Manitoba,
   Canada, is described in all stages and both sexes. Five additional
   species of Cryptotendipes Kieffer are recorded from Lake Winnipeg, and
   two from South Indian Lake. C. ariel (Sublette) is shown to be a senior
   synonym of C. darbyi (Sublette). The pupae and larvae of C. emorsus
   (Townes), C. casuarius (Townes), C. darbyi and C. pseudotener
   (Goetghebuer) are described or redescribed. The female of C. emorsus is
   described and additional information given on other male and female
   imagines. Keys are given to known pupae and larvae of Cryptotendipes.
   The distribution of Cryptotendipes in Lake Winnipeg is mapped and
   discussed. The separation of larval instars is shown approximately to
   follow Dyar's rule.
C1 Saether, Ole A.; The Natural History Museum, Bergen Museum, University
   of Bergen, N-5007 Bergen, Norway, Norway.
EM ole.sather@zmb.uib.no

AU Wang, Ming-Fu

   Ao, Hu
SO Zootaxa
VL 2412
PS 53-62
PD 29 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2412.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02412p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Holarctic genus Piezura Rondani (Diptera, Fanniidae) is reviewed.
   Phylogenetic relationships among the species in this group, as well as
   the biogeography of these species, are discussed on the basis of a
   cladistic analysis. Piezura graminicola shanxiensis Xue, Wang and Wu,
   1998 is redescribed and elevated to species rank based on comparison of
   its morphology and phylogenetic relationships. Syllegopterula flava
   Hsue, 1983 and its replacement name Thricops flavidus Xue, 1998 are
   treated as junior synonyms of Piezura graminicola (Zetterstedt, 1846).
C1 Zhang, Dong; College of Biological Sciences and Biotechnology, Beijing
   Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China, China.
EM ernest8445@163.com
RI Zhang, Dong/J-2296-2014
OI Zhang, Dong/0000-0001-6427-7867
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   General morphology; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones
DE Piezura [General morphology / Adult morphological characters /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography / Historical zooeography /
   ] [Land zones / Holarctic region / distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Fanniidae, Muscidae
OR Piezura - Rondani 1866 (Fanniidae). 
   Piezura graminicola - (Zetterstedt 1846) (Fanniidae): [Syn nov,
   Syllegopterula flava Hsue 1983, p. 58; Syn nov, Thricops flavidus Xue in
   Xue & Chao 1998, p. 58].

   shanxiensis, p. 59].

   Tubau area, block E2K, 16[long dash]VIII[long dash]2009; both to be
   deposited in the RMNH Leiden, The Netherlands.

DT Article
TI Two new species of genus Tetrix (Orthoptera: Tetrigidae) from Henan
   Province.
AU Zhao, Ling
   Niu, Yao
   Zheng, Zhe-min (zhengzhemin@163.com) 
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 29
IS 2
PS 197-199
PD March 28 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper, two new species of Tetrigidae: Tetrix jigongshanensis
   sp.nov. and Tetrix glochinota sp.nov., are described. Type specimens
   were deposited in the Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University.
   1. Tetrix jigongshanensis sp.nov. This new species is similar to Tetrix
   cavifrontalis Liang, 1998, but differs by the following: 1) anterior
   margin of vertex is straight; 2) in profile, the vertex and frontal
   ridge forms an obtuse angular; 3) in profile, the frontal ridge
   straightens before the lateral ocelli; 4) in profile, the upper margin
   of the pronotum arcs; 5) the anterior margin of the pronotum is obtuse
   angular; 6) the hind process of the pronotum reaches the middle of the
   hind femur; 7) the hind wing doesn't reach the top of the hind process;
   8) the width of the midfemur is wider than the width of the elytra.
   Length of body: [female] 7.5[approximately]8 mm; length of pronotum:
   [female] 5.5[approximately]6 mm; length of hind femur: [female]
   5[approximately]5.5 mm. Holotype [female], Henan: Xinyang (Jigongshan)
   114[degree]1[minute]E, 31[degree]7[minute]N, 29-June-1992, collected by
   Niu Yao; paratype, 1 [female] Same data as holotype. 2. Tetrix
   glochinota sp.nov. This new species is similar to Tetrix simulans
   (B.-Bienko), 1929 and Tetrix yunlongensis Zheng et Mao, 2002. It differs
   from both in the following: 1) the anterior margin of the vertex is
   straight; 2) in profile, the upper margin of the pronotum is globular in
   the anterior half and has a flat hind part; 3) the hind process reaches
   the top of the hind femur. It differs from the former by: 1) in profile,
   the frontal ridge concaves before lateral ocelli; 2) the width of the
   midfemur is wider than the width of the elytra. It differs from the
   latter by width of vertex which is 1.7 times of an eye. Length of body:
   [female] 9.5[approximately]10 mm; length of pronotum: [female]
   10[approximately]10.5 mm; length of hind femur: [female]
   5[approximately]6 mm. Holotype [female], Henan: Tongbai
   113[degree]3[minute]E, 32[degree]3[minute]N, 17-July-2001, collected by
   Niu yao; paratypes, 2 [female] Same data as holotype.
C1 Zheng, Zhe-min; Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an
   710062, China, China.
EM zhengzhemin@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Tetrix glochinota; Tetrix jigongshanensis [Henan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Tetrix glochinota (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Henan, P. 198]. 
   Tetrix jigongshanensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Henan, P. 198]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610071551
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species of Tautocerus Anufriev from China (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae: Idiocerinae).
AU Li, Zi-zhong (lizizhong38@163.com) 
   Song, Yue-hua
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 29
IS 2
PS 203-204
PD March 28 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Tautocerus Anufriev, Tautocerus wangmoensis sp. nov. is
   described from China. This new species is similar to T. serristleus
   Zhang, Li et Qi, but can be distinguished by the following
   characteristics: 1) vertex without black round spot; 2) a small
   cone-like protrusion of the pygofer side at near end margin; 3) shape of
   style is dissimilar. Holotype [male], paratypes 12[male][male],
   15[female] [female], Wangmo, Guizhou, 2009-04-26-27, collect by ZHANG
   Zheng-guang, DAI Ren-huai and SONG Qiong-zhang. The type specimens are
   deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Guizhou University.
C1 Li, Zi-zhong; Institute of Entomology, Guizhou Agricultural College,
   Guiyang 550025, China, China.
EM lizizhong38@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083

   Eurasia; Asia; China

DT Article
TI A REVIEW OF THE FRUIT FLY TRIBE TEPHRELLINI (DIPTERA: TEPHRITIDAE:
   TEPHRITINAE) IN THE INDO-AUSTRALIAN REGION.
AU Hancock, D.L.
SO Australian Entomologist
VL 37
IS 1
PS 1-6
PD Mar 26 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eight genera and 17 species of Indo-Australian Tephritidae arc placed in
   the tribe Tephrellini. Pristaciura Hendel and Indaciura Hering are
   removed from synonymy with Oxyaciura Hendel and Indaciura is placed as a
   new synonym of Pristaciura, resulting in three new combinations: P.
   formosae (Hendel), P. monochaeta (Bezzi) and P. xanthotricha (Bezzi).
   Pristaciura incisa Hendel, stat, rev, is removed from synonymy with P.
   xanthotricha, with which it has been widely confused. A key to the
   genera is included.
C1 Hancock, D.L.; POB 2464, Cairns, Qld, Australia, Australia.
SC Zoology
SN 1320-6133
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Land zones; Australasian region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Tephrellini [Australasian region / Indo-Australian region / Key to
   genera] [Asia /  / ] [ /  / Distribution; systematics] [Australasia /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Tephritidae
OR Indaciura formosae - Hendel (Tephritidae): [Referred to, Pristaciura, p.
   4]. 
   Indaciura monochaeta - Bezzi (Tephritidae): [Referred to, Pristaciura,
   p. 4]. 
   Indaciura xanthotricha - Bezzi (Tephritidae): [Referred to, Pristaciura,
   p. 4]. 
   Oxyaciura - Hendel (Tephritidae): [Removal from synonymy, Pristaciura
   Hendel, p. 3]. 
   Pristaciura - Hendel (Tephritidae): [Syn nov, Indaciura Hering, p. 3;
   Removal from synonymy, With Oxyaciura Hendel, p. 3]. 
   Pristaciura formosae - (Hendel) (Tephritidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Indaciura, p. 4]. 
   Pristaciura incisa - Hendel (Tephritidae): [Removal from synonymy, With
   Pristaciura xanthotricha (Bezzi), p. 4]. 
   Pristaciura monochaeta - (Bezzi) (Tephritidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Indaciura, p. 4]. 
   Pristaciura xanthotricha - (Bezzi) (Tephritidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Indaciura, p. 4; Removal from synonymy, Pristaciura incisa Hendel,
   p. 4]. 
   Tephrellini (Tephritidae): [Key to genera, Asia, Indo-Australian region
   & Australasian region, Indo-Australian region, P. 1].

DT Article
TI DISTRIBUTION OF ACROPHTALMIA CHIONE FELDER & FELDER, 1867, WITH
   DESCRIPTIONS OF TWO NEW SUBSPECIES FROM EASTERN INDONESIA (LEPIDOPTERA:
   NYMPHALIDAE: SATYRINAE).
AU Tennent, W. John
   Miller, Jacqueline Y.
   Rawlins, Andrew
SO Bulletin of the Allyn Museum
VL 162
PS 1-7
PD 26 March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The distribution of Acrophtalmia chione Felder & Felder, 1867, is
   discussed. The species is recorded for the first time from Kasiruta,
   Mandioli and Ternate in North Maluku. Two new subspecies: A. chione
   lucidus new subspecies (Bacan) and A. c. orientalis new subspecies
   (Arfak Mountains) are described and illustrated. A record of A. chione
   from Buru is questioned. In addition, a new island record of Taliabu is
   provided for A. leuce chionides de Niceville, 1900.
C1 Tennent, W. John; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Entomol, Cromwell Rd, London,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
SC Zoology
SN 0097-3211

   Eurasia; Asia

    / New subspecies]. 
   Acrophtalmia leuce chionides [Indonesia / Moluccas, Sula Islands,
   Taliabu / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

DT Article
TI Taxonomic remarks on some genera of Lixini Schoenherr, 1823 (Coleoptera:
   Curculionidae).
AU Gultekin, Levent (lgutekin@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2411
PS 1-21
PD 26 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2411.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02411p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Types of forty-six species of Lixini of the genera Broconius
   Desbrochers, 1904, and Lixus Fabricius, 1801 were examined to evaluate
   their status, and lectotypes were designated (or holotypes recognized)
   when necessary. New synonyms, homonyms, combinations and new names were
   established as follows: Lixus Fabricius, 1801 (= Broconius Desbrochers,
   1904 syn. n.), Lixus rectirostris Faust, 1890 (= Lixus rectirostris
   Desbrochers, 1904 hom et syn. n. = Broconius helenae Alonso-Zarazaga &
   Lyal, 1999 syn. n. = Lixus rectirostris Faust subsp. infrequens
   Hoffmann, 1954 syn. n.), Lixus kraatzi Capiomont, 1875 (= Lixus confinis
   Petri, 1904 syn. n.), Lixus isfahanensis nom. n. (= Larinus cylindrus
   (Hoffmann, 1963) not Lixus cylindrus (Fabricius, 1781) comb. et hom.
   n.), Lixus scolopax Boheman, 1835 (Lixus lutescens Capiomont, 1875 syn.
   n. = Lixus operculifer Petri, 1904 syn. n. = Lixus ewaldi Alziar, 1978
   syn. n.), Conorhynchus mixtus (Fabricius, 1792) (= Lixus semilunatus
   Petri, 1904 comb. et syn. n.), Lixus elegantulus Boheman, 1842 (= Lixus
   amplirostris Petri, 1904 syn. n. = Lixus colchicus Petri, 1904 syn. n. =
   Lixus convexicollis Petri, 1904 syn. n.), and Lixus nordmanni Hochhuth,
   1847 (= Lixus iridis v. levantinus Petri, 1904 syn. n.).
C1 Gultekin, Levent; Ataturk University, Faculty of Agriculture, Department
   of Plant Protection, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey, Turkey.

   Curculionidae

   semilunatus (Petri 1904), p. 19].

   isfahanensis, p. 8]. 
   Lixus elegantulus - Boheman 1842 (Curculionidae): [Syn nov, Lixus

   Lixus farinifer - Reitter 1892 (Curculionidae): [Lectotype designated,

   Lixus fascifarius - Reitter 1895 (Curculionidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 16].

   P. 11].

PT J
AN ZOOR14605037959
DT Article
TI Grass-flower thrips of the genus Chirothrips (Thysanoptera: Thripidae),
   with a key to species from Iran.
AU Minaei, Kambiz (kminaei@shirazu.ac.ir) 
   Mound, Laurence
SO Zootaxa
VL 2411
PS 33-43
PD 26 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2411.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/f/zt02411p043.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Species of the genus Chirothrips Haliday breed and pupate only within
   grass florets. Each larva is restricted to a single floret, and adult
   body size is thus presumably related to floret size. Despite this, some
   Chirothrips species are distinguished only on states that are related to
   body size. The validity of some commonly recorded members of the C.
   manicatus species-group, including C. africanus and C. pallidicornis, is
   therefore considered questionable. Character states that have been used
   to define the genus Agrostothrips Hood are shown to be variable, and
   this genus is placed as a new synonym of Chirothrips. An identification
   key, based on illustrated structural differences, is provided to the
   Chirothrips known from Iran: C. aculeatus, C. atricorpus, C.
   kurdistanus, C. manicatus, C. meridionalis and C. molestus.
C1 Minaei, Kambiz; Department of Plant Protection, College of Agriculture,
   Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran, Iran.
EM kminaei@shirazu.ac.ir
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Chirothrips [Plant hosts / Poaceae / Host parasite relationships;
   taxonomic implications] [Iran /  / Key to species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Thysanoptera
OR Chirothrips - Haliday 1836 (Thysanoptera): [Syn nov, Agrostothrips Hood
   1954, p. 34; Key to species, Iran, P. 38; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14605037959
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI Two new genera of the tribe Parahiraciini (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha:
   Issidae) from China.
AU Zhang, Zheng-Guang (chenxs3218@163.com) 
   Chen, Xiang-Sheng
SO Zootaxa
VL 2411
PS 44-52
PD 26 Mar 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2010/2411.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2010/1/zt02411p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new issid genera of the tribe Parahiraciini (Hemiptera:
   Fulgoromorpha: Issidae) are described from China: Paratetricodes gen.
   nov. and Fusiissus gen. nov. Two new species, Paratetricodes sinensis
   sp. nov. (China: Guizhou, Guangxi) and Fusiissus frontomaculatus sp.
   nov. (China: Guizhou), are described and illustrated. The tribe
   Parahiraciini is discussed briefly. A key to the genera in the tribe
   Parahiraciini is given.

   China, China.

AB The blaberid genus Schistopeltis Rehn is rediagnosed. Schistopeltis
   microschistos n. sp. is described and the genus is recorded for the
   first time from Colombia. A taxonomic key is given to distinguish the
   new taxon from the previously known species S. peculiaris (from Brazil)
   and S. lizeri (from Bolivia).

TI Gomeda Distant (Hemiptera: Flatidae: Selizini), a New Record for China
   with Description of a New Species.
AU Peng, Ling-fei (yinglunw@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
   Zhang, Ya-lin
   Wang, Ying-lun
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 32
IS 1
PS 29-32
PD Mar 25 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with one new record genus Gomeda Distant and one new
   species G. unicolorata, sp. nov. from China. A key to species of the
   genus is provided and the adult and its female genitalia are
   illustrated. The type specimens are kept in the Institute of Zoology,
   Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing. Gomeda unicolorata, sp. nov.
   (Figs. 1-11) This new species resembles G. abdominalis (Kirby), but
   differs from the latter in: 1) abdomen without oblique fuscous lateral
   fascia on each side; 2) tegmen about 3.00 times as long as broad, and
   the costal margin less sinuate; 3) frons with very short median carina
   in the middle area; 4) costal membrane about 1.80 times as wide as
   costal cell. Holotype: [female], Simao City, Yunnan Province,
   11-1V-1955, coll. Kryzhanovskiy; Paratype: 1[female], 50 km Southwest of
   Mojiang, Yunnan Province, 29-111-1955, coll. Kryzhanovskiy.
C1 Peng, Ling-fei; NW A&F Univ, Entomol Museum, Yangling, Shaanxi, China,
   China.
EM yinglunw@nwsuaf.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Gomeda [China /  / New record]. 
   Gomeda unicolorata [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Flatidae
OR Gomeda - Distant 1906 (Flatidae): [Key to species, P. 30; New record]. 
   Gomeda unicolorata (Flatidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 30].

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Ampulex (Hymenoptera: Ampulicidae) from
   China.
AU Chen, Guo-hua
   Li, Qiang (liqiangkm@126.com) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 32
IS 1
PS 43-46
PD Mar 25 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Ampulex clypecomplana Chen et Li, sp. nov., is described
   from Yunnan Province, China. The type specimen is deposited in the
   Insect Collections of Yunnan Agricultural University. Ampulex
   clypecomplana Chen et Li, sp. nov. (Figs. 1-9) The new species is
   similar to Ampulex dissector (Thunberg, 1822). It can be easily
   distinguished from the latter by the following characters: clypeus with
   median carina not extending to its apical margin, apical margin
   emarginate and flat; vertex coarsely, with dense longitudinally rugose
   and large punctures; gena with dense rugulose and small puncture;
   pronotum roughly square, with irregularly transverse rugulose, without
   median longitudinal groove; posterior margin of metanotum withshort,
   longitudinal carina and small punctuates; sternum VIII near trapezia,
   posterior margin inconspicuously emarginated; male genitalia: aedeagal
   apical with 7 teeth on ventral edge. Holotype [male], Baimengkong
   Village, Qibailu Township, Mengzi County, Honghe Pretecture, Yunnan
   Province, China, 21-IV-2006, WANG He-sheng.
C1 Li, Qiang; Yunnan Agr Univ, Coll Plant Protect, Kunming, Yunnan, China,
   China.
EM liqiangkm@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ampulex clypecomplana [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Sphecoidea, Sphecidae

DT Article
TI A New Species of Genus Ammophila Kirby (Hymenoptera: Sphecidae) from
   China.
AU Yan, Cheng-jin
   Li, Qiang (liqiangkm@126.com) 
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 32
IS 1
PS 47-50
PD Mar 25 2010
PY 2010
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Ammophila antenniferruginea Yan et Li, sp. nov., from
   Xinjiang, China, is described. The type specimen is deposited in the
   Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China.
   Ammophila antenniferruginea Yan et Li, sp. nov. (Figs. 1-5) The female
   of this species can be distinguished from the similar Ammophila
   rubigegen Li et Yang (1990) and other species of the genus by the
   following combination of characters: metanotum with coarse, transverse
   rugae; propodeal enclosure with coarse, transverse rugae medially, and
   coarse, oblique rugae laterally, without longitudinal carina medially;
   the free margin of clypeus with two lateral teeth; clypeal disk
   moderately elevated medially; antenna largely, leg largely, base half of
   petiole reddish brown; apex half of petiole reddish yellow; setae on
   head black, long, on clypeus, frons, thorax lacking. Holotype: [female],
   Tuoli County, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China, 04-VII-1995,
   coll. MA Shi-jun, XIA Kai-ling. Etymology: The specific name is derived
   from the Latin "antenn-" and "ferruginea".
C1 Li, Qiang; Yunnan Agr Univ, Coll Plant Protect, Kunming, Yunnan, China,
   China.
EM liqiangkm@126.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7482
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ammophila antenniferruginea [Xinjiang Uygur /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Sphecoidea, Sphecidae

   48].

   Fan, Zi-de
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 32

PS 55-58
PD Mar 25 2010

TI A taxonomic review of Nola angustipennis Inoue and an allied new species
   (Nolinae, Nolidae).
AU Sasaki, Akio
   Jinbo, Utsugi
SO Japan Heterocerists' Journal
VL 256
PS 121-123
PD 25 March 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Inoue (2001, Japan Heterocerists' J. 212) redescribed Nola angustipennis
   Inoue, 1982, and described an allied new species N. kontaii from Ryukyu
   Islands. Japan. We had a chance to review this species complex on the
   basis of many additional samples and revealed that N. komaii is
   conspecific with N. angustipennis. and that N. angustipennis sensu
   Inoue. 2001 is another undescribed species. Consequently, we regard N.
   komaii as a synonym of N. angustipennis and describe the allied new
   species as below. Nola angustipennis Inoue, 1982. Nola angustipennis
   Inoue, 1982, Moths Japan 1: 662, 2: 343, pl. 349, figs 3, 16. Nola
   komaii Inoue, 2001, Japan Heterocerists' J. 212: 224, figs 9, 10, 15,
   16, 17, syn. n. Wingspan I6-18mm. Forewing: Costal and dorsal margin
   weakly convex; ground colour varies from whitish gray to blackish brown;
   postmedial and antemedial line blackish brown, each double lines,
   antemedial line arched, gently bent to outside; basal portion same as
   ground colour, except for the costal margin. Male genitalia. Valva
   bifurcate, sacculus weakly sclerotised, gradually sclerotised apically,
   ended with a small strong spine; aedeagus length about 4 times of its
   width; coecum penis long and pointed; cornutus absent. Female genitalia.
   Antrum small, weakly sclerotised; ductus bursae long and narrow; corpus
   bursae oval; signum elongate spindle-shape, with a mass of granules.
   Examined materials are as stated in the main text. Distribution:
   Iriomote Is., Ryukyus. Remarks. The forewing shows significant colour
   variations. The holotype of N. angustipennis is a blackish form in those
   variations. The larvae feed on flowers of Bruguiera gymnorrhiza (L.)
   Lam. (Rhizophoraceae). Nola furumii sp. n. Nola angustipennis Inoue,
   2001. Japan Heterocerists' J. 212: 224, figs 7, 8, 13, 14 (nec Inoue.
   1982). Wingspan 11-15mm. Smaller than in angustipennis. Forewing: Shape
   nearly rectangle; ground colour more blackish than in angustipennis;
   area between postmedial and antemedial lines sometimes whitish;
   postmedial line weakly dentate; antemedial line bent at vein CuA,
   becoming wide toward inner margin; basal portion blackish brown. Male
   genitalia. Similar to angustipennis; but can be distinguished from the
   latter as follows. Sacculus less sclerotised; the apical spine much
   longer and more straightish, aedeagus shorter, about 3 times of its
   width; coecum penis broad and blunt. Female genitalia. Antrum wide and
   long, cylindrical, weakly sclerotised; ductus bursae shorter than in
   angustipennis, almost as long as antrum; corpus bursae pyriform; signum
   absent. Holotype and paratypes are as stated in the main text. Remarks.
   Inoue (2001) stated that the male genitalia of this species (N.
   angustipennis, sensu Inoe, 2001) and the former species were almost
   identical. However, the apical spine on the sacculus and the aedeagus
   are significantly different between the two species. The larvae feed on
   Kandelia obovata Sheue, H. Y. Liu et W. H. Yong (Rhizophoraceae).
SC Zoology
SN 0286-3537
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Nola furumii [Japan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Nolidae
OR Nola angustipennis - Inoue 1982 (Nolidae): [Syn nov, Nola komaii Inoue
   2001, p. 122]. 
   Nola furumii (Nolidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 122].

DT Article
TI Description of five new Stigmella and one Bohemmania species from Japan,
   with a new record of one Bohemannia species (Lepidoptera, Nepticulidae).
AU Hirano, Nagao
SO Japan Heterocerists' Journal
VL 256
PS 124-134
PD 25 March 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nepticulidae is a large family of microlepidoptera. At present, 51
   described species have been known from Japan (Diskus & Puplesis, 2003).
   In this paper, five new species of the genus Stigmella and one new
   species of the genus Bohemannia are described. The holotypes will be
   deposited in the collection of National Museum of Nature and Science
   (NSMT); the paratypes will be deposited in the collection of NSMT and
   the Osaka Prefectural University (OPU). Specimens examined are given in
   the main text. In addition, Bohemannia ussuriella Puplesis is firstly
   recorded from Japan. The ruficapitella group Stigmella crenatiella sp.
   nov. (Figs 3,15,21,25) Stigmella sp. 1, Owada et al., 2006: 41, fig. 4.
   Stigmella sp. 3, Oku, 2003: 8. Wingspan 4.0-5.0 mm, forewing length
   1.8mm - 2.3mm. Head: tuft orange, scape and coller deep yellow-brown.
   Forewing fuscous with leaden shine; in male, underside with a Vertical
   line of erected scales; cilia fuscous. Hindwing and cilia light grayish
   brown. Male genitalia (Fig. 15): valva broad, cuiller rounded, style
   slender and simple; uncus a pair of large triangular processes;
   posterior arm of gnathos slender, elongate; lateral arm of transtilla
   short and large; aedeagus very large, with cornuti a band of numerous
   minute processes basally and developed prominents apically; manica
   absent. Female genitalia (Fig. 21): anterior apophyses as long as
   posterior apophyses; bursa copulatrix ovate-shaped, without signum;
   accessory sac large, with a spiny and elongate duct, and an elongate
   sclerotized band bearing minute spines; ductus spermathecae with six
   convolutions. Remarks. This species is similar to S. aladina Puplesis
   (host: Quercus) but smaller in size (wingspan 4.9-5.8mm in S. aladina).
   The male is without erected scale line on the underside of its forewing
   (present in S. aladina). The female can be distinguished from the latter
   by the larger accessory sac with the much larger sclerorized band.Host
   plant. Castanea crenata Sieb. et Zucc. (Fagaceae). See Fig. 25 for the
   mine. Distribution. Japan (Honshu). Stigmella azuminoensis sp. nov.
   (Figs 5, 10-11, 18, 29-33) Wingspan 5.3mm-5.8mm, forewing length
   2.4mm-2.7mm. Head: tuft orange, scape shiny ocherous, collar reddish
   purple, antenna dark purple. Forewing dark purplish copper with a silver
   fascia at 4/6; cilia brown. Hindwing and cilia brown. Male genitalia
   (Figs 10-11): valva broad, cuiller with a finger-like process, style
   slender; uncus with small triangular processes widely separated; gnathos
   a semicircular plate; ventral arm of transtilla a short transverse bar;
   aedeagus stout, cornuti a wide band of minute processes posteriorly and
   rather large thorns anteriorly; manica absent. Female genitalia (Figs
   18): anterior apophyses wide; bursa copulatrix twice as long as
   accessory sac, with minute pectinations; accessory sac wrinkled; ductus
   spermathecae with three convolutions. Remarks. This species has unique
   characters among the Holarctic nepticulid species such as the
   semicircular gnathos in the male genitalia and tergal blackish spots of
   the larva (Figs 32-33). In addition, the larvae pierce the leaf surface
   when they change direction (Fig. 31); this behavior is also unique to
   this species. Host plant. Quercus serrata Thunb., Q. dentata Thunb., Q.
   acutissima Carruth. (Fagaceae). See Figs 29-31 for mines. Distribution.
   Japan (Honshu). Stigmella hisakoae sp. nov. (Figs 1-2, 12,19, 26)
   Stigmella sp. 4, Oku, 2003: 9. Wingspan 4.9mm-6.7mm, forewing length
   2.1mm-2.9mm. Head: tuft orange, scape and collar creamy; antenna
   fuscous. Forewing fuscous with pale yellowish fascia at 4/6; cilia pale
   grayish brown. Hindwing and cilia fuscous with blue-purplish sheen in
   male, pale grayish brown in female. Male genitalia (Fig. 12): valva
   short, style a large thorn; uncus trapezoidal, bifircated gnathos
   band-like, the lower edge widely concaved ventral arm of transtilla
   slender, oblique bar; aedeagu stout, cornuti consisting of a basal mass
   of minute processes basally, an median row of large prominents and a
   group of large apical thorns. Female genitalia (Fig 19): anterior and
   posterior apophyses slender; burs; copulatrix large, ovate, with minute
   pectinations accessory sac rather small; ductus spermathecae witl two or
   three convolutions. Remarks. Similar to S. fervida Puplesis in
   appearance but the fascia of forewing is wider than the latter species
   The male genitalia is similar to that of S. lithocarpella van Nieukerken
   & Liu, but can be separated from thi latter by the less pointed arm of
   gnathos, the not-toilet vesica lacking apical thorns. Host plant.
   Quercus serrata Thunb. (Fagaceae) Distribution. Japan (Honshu). Species
   group unassigned Stigmella morivora sp. nov. (Figs 4, 14, 20, 27)
   Wingspan 3.7mm-4.3mm, forewing length 1.7mm-2.0mm. Head: tuft orange,
   scape and collar yellov ocherous; antenna fuscous. Forewing dark copper
   will blue-purplish shine; cilia fuscous. Hindwing and cilii grayish
   ocherous. Male genitalia (Fig. 14): valy< elongate, style a large
   horn-shaped; uncus a pair of wide triangular processes; gnathos narrow,
   posterior arm long and slender; ventral arm of transtilla elongate
   anterolaterally; aedeagus with sclerotized apex with < long projection,
   cornuti 14-16 large conical processes Female genitalia (Fig. 20):
   anterior and posterior apophyses long; bursa copulatrix wide, with
   minute pectinations; ductus spermathecae elongate, spiral. Remarks. The
   male genitalia is similar to that of S paliurella (Klimesch), but can be
   separated from the latter by the longer ventral arm of transtilla, the
   flavinculum, the aedeagus with an apical sclerotized arei and the more
   thorns of cornuti. Further study is needec to determine the taxonomic
   position of this species, ever if this species shows similarities to the
   paliurella specie: group. Morus (Moraceae) is firstly recorded as a hos
   plant of the Nepticulidae. Host plant. Morus bombycis Koidzumi
   (Moraceae) See Fig. 27 for the mine. istribution. Japan (Honshu). The
   salicis group Stigmella azusa sp. nov. (Figs 6, 13, 22, 28)Wingspan
   4.4mm-5.2mm, forewing length 2.0mm-2.4mm. Head: tuft orange, scape and
   collar pale yellow ocherous; antenna glossy blackish. Forewing dark
   metallic brown, tinged with dark blue-purplish sheen al apical half;
   median fascia light yellow; cilia glossy gray Hindwing glossy gray;
   cilia creamy. Male genitalia (Fig 13): valva long, cuiller angled, style
   a arched large thorn; uncus trapezoidal with a pair of small
   projections; gnathos with an elongate median arm slightly tapering
   toward apex; cornuti two or three large thorns and 7-10 small thorns.
   Female genitalia (Fig. 22): anterior apophyses narrow, longer than
   posterior apophyses; ductus bursae with long folds; bursa copulatrix
   ovate, with minute pectinations and a band-like signum of pectinations
   (Fig. 22a); accessory sac small, ductus spermathecae narrow. Remarks.
   The gnathos of male genitalia with median process is unique to the
   salicis group. Host plant. Salix serissaefolia Kimura (Salicaceae). See
   Fig. 28 for the mine. Distribution. Japan (Honshu). Bohemannia
   nipponicella sp. nov. (Figs 7-8, 17, 23) Bohemannia sp., Hirano, 2009:
   50 pl. 1, fig. 3. Wingspan 6.5mm-9.0mm, forewing length 2.9mm-4.0mm.
   Head: tuft orange, scape pale golden yellow; collar glossy red-purple;
   antenna fuscous and whitish apically. Forewing glossy, ground color
   variable from copper to purplish; a fascia at 4/6 golden yellow, very
   variable from a wide band to a narrow line interrupted medially; cilia
   fuscous. Hindwing and cilia fuscous. Male genitalia (Fig. 17): valva
   broad with pointed apex; uncus simple; gnathos with a median arm
   tapering toward apex; aedeagus large, carina variable, cornuti a pair of
   large bars and two spots of minute spines. Female genitalia (Fig. 23):
   posterior apophyses often spatulate apically; a constructed area between
   ductus bursae and vestibulum with a pair of long sclerite; bursa
   copulatrix long, with two reticulate signa; ductus spermathecae narrow,
   coiled. Remarks This species closely related to B. manschurella Puplesis
   and B. quadrimaculella (Boheman), but separated from these species by
   the cornuti with a pair of large bars and two spots of minute spines.
   Host plant. Unknown. Distribution. Japan (Hokkaido, Honshu). Bohemannia
   ussuriella Puplesis, 1984 (Figs 9, 16, 24) Wingspan 5.8mm-7.2mm,
   forewing length 2.6mm-3.3mm. Very similar to the previous species but
   can be separated from the latter by the smaller size and the shorter
   antennae, the male genitalia (Fig. 16) with the rounded apex of valva
   and the vesica with short and long bar-shaped large cornuti, and the
   female genitalia (Fig. 24) with the longer corpus bursae. Remarks. The
   short bar-shaped cornutus is not shown in the figure of original
   desctiption (Puplesis, 1994). The female genitalia is figured for the
   first time. Host plant. Unknown. Distribution. Japan (new record,
   Hokkaido and Honshu), Russian Far East.

DT Article
TI Evidence for a new species of Cryptosporidium infecting tortoises:
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci.
AU Traversa, Donato (dtraversa@unite.it) 
SO Parasites & Vectors
VL 3
IS 21
PS 1-4
PD 25 March 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.parasitesandvectors.com/content/pdf/1756-3305-3-21.pdf
AW http://www.parasitesandvectors.com/content/pdf/1756-3305-3-21.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cryptosporidiosis affects the gastrointestinal and respiratory tract of
   humans as well as of a wide range of companion, farm, laboratory and
   wild animals. In the past few years, three independent studies have
   provided strong evidence for the existence of a distinct Cryptosporidium
   species affecting tortoises and likely circulating in other reptile
   species as well. A new Cryptosporidium genotype was firstly detected and
   genetically characterized in a marginated tortoise in Italy in 2007 and
   named Cryptosporidium sp. ex Testudo marginata CrIT-20. The phylogenetic
   analysis of this isolate indicated that this Cryptosporidium was unique
   and belonged to the intestinal clade. These findings were later on
   confirmed by the detection of genetic homologies of isolates from a
   python and a chameleon from Spain and by recent research in the United
   States. The latter study presented both the occurrence of intestinal
   lesions in a pancake tortoise and a Russian tortoise and the genetic
   characterization of the isolates, together with the first pictures of
   the endogenous stages of Cryptosporidium CrIT-20. Phylogenetic inference
   based on the sequences representing small subunit of the nuclear
   ribosomal RNA gene (SSU) of these isolates confirmed the pathological
   findings because this Cryptosporidium was related to the intestinal
   group and supported previous results in T. marginata from Italy. The
   present scientific data on the Cryptosporidium CrIT-20 support its
   classification as a new species of Cryptosporidium causing intestinal
   diseases in tortoises. Although further morphological (i.e. exogenous
   stages) and biological aspects (i.e. complete host range) are yet to be
   elucidated, it is proposed that this Cryptosporidium is designated
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci.
C1 Traversa, Donato; Department of Comparative Biomedical Sciences,
   University of Teramo, Italy, Italy.
EM dtraversa@unite.it
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1756-3305
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; North America
DE Chamaeleo calyptratus; Python regius [Protozoan parasites /
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci / New parasite species] [Spain /  / New
   protozoan parasite species]. 
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci [Reptilian hosts / Chamaeleo calyptratus /
   New parasite species] [ / Malacochersus tornieri / ] [ / Python regius /
   ] [ / Testudo horsefeldii / ] [ / Testudo marginata / ] [Italy /  / New
   species from reptilian host] [Spain /  / ] [USA /  / ]. 
   Malacochersus tornieri; Testudo horsefeldii [Protozoan parasites /
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci / New parasite species] [USA /  / New
   protozoan parasite species]. 
   Testudo marginata [Protozoan parasites / Cryptosporidium ducismarci /
   New parasite species] [Italy /  / New protozoan parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Protozoans; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Anapsida, Testudines,
   Cryptodira, Testudinidae, Lepidosauria, Squamata, Sauria,
   Chamaeleontidae, Serpentes, Boidae, Protozoa, Apicomplexa, Sporozoea,
   Coccidia
OR Malacochersus tornieri (Testudinidae): [Host]. 
   Testudo horsefeldii (Testudinidae): [Host]. 
   Testudo marginata (Testudinidae): [Host]. 
   Chamaeleo calyptratus (Chamaeleontidae): [Host]. 
   Python regius (Boidae): [Host]. 
   Cryptosporidium ducismarci (Coccidia): [Sp nov, Type locality not given,
   P. 3; Parasite].
