PT J
AN ZOOR14608051652
PM 20097822
DT Article
TI Bacterial symbionts of the brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens
   (Homoptera: Delphacidae).
AU Tang, Ming
   Lv, Lu
   Jing, Shengli
   Zhu, Lili
   He, Guangcun (gche@whu.edu.cn) 
SO Applied and Environmental Microbiology
VL 76
IS 6
PS 1740-1745
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 2
U2 37
AB The brown planthopper (Nilaparvata lugens Stal), the most destructive
   pest of rice, has been identified, including biotypes with high
   virulence towards previously resistant rice varieties. There have also
   been many reports of a yeast-like symbiont of N. lugens, but little is
   known about the bacterial microbes. In this study, we examined the
   bacterial microbes in N. lugens and identified a total of 18 operational
   taxonomic units (OTUs) representing four phyla (Proteobacteria,
   Firmicutes, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes) by sequencing and
   analyzing 16S rRNA gene libraries obtained from three populations of N.
   lugens, which were maintained on the rice varieties TN1, Mudgo, and
   ASD7. Several of the OTUs were similar to previously reported secondary
   symbionts of other insects, including an endosymbiont of the psyllid
   Glycapsis brimblecombei, an Asaia sp. found in the mosquito Anopheles
   stephensi, and Wolbachia, found in the mite Metaseiulus occidentalis.
   However, the species and numbers of the detected OTUs differed
   substantially among the N. lugens populations. Further, in situ
   hybridization analysis using digoxigenin-labeled probes indicated that
   OTU 1 was located in hypogastrium tissues near the ovipositor and ovary
   in biotype 1 insects, while OTU 2 was located in the front of the
   ovipositor sheath in biotype 2 insects. In addition, masses of
   bacterium-like organisms were observed in the tubes of salivary sheaths
   in rice plant tissues that the insects had fed upon. The results provide
   indications of the diversity of the bacterial microbes harbored by the
   brown planthopper and of possible associations between specific
   bacterial microbes and biotypes of N. lugens.
C1 He, Guangcun; Wuhan Univ, Coll Life Sci, Wuhan, China, China.
EM gche@whu.edu.cn
OI He, Guangcun/0000-0001-6395-4774
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0099-2240
BD Associations; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Nilaparvata lugens [Associations / Bacteria / Bacterial symbiont survey
   & functional analysis; host parasite relationships; biotypes 1; 2 & 3]
   [Plant hosts / Rice / bacterial associates] [Hubei / Wuhan / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Fulgoroidea, Delphacidae
OR Nilaparvata lugens (Delphacidae): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14608051652
OA Bronze, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14607045964
DT Article
TI Some net-winged midges (Diptera: Blephariceridae) from New Caledonia.
AU Zwick, Peter
   Mary-Sasal, Nathalie
SO Aquatic Insects
VL 32
IS 1
PS 1-23
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB New taxa and previously unavailable life stages of known species of
   Diptera: Blephariceridae from New Caledonia are described. Curupirina
   comosipes sp. n. differs distinctly from the three named species in the
   genus. However, separating larvae of the other species was not possible.
   Descriptions of the male and first instar larva of Nesocurupira
   curtirostris Stuckenberg are added. All life stages of Stuckenbergina
   hystrix gen. et sp. n. are described. A single larva of it had in the
   past been reported as possible Paltostomatinae (today classified as a
   tribe, Paltostomatini). However, all New Caledonian net-winged midges
   belong to Apistomyiini. All are endemic, and three of them even of
   restricted distribution on the main island.
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0424
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

    / biology; distribution]. 
   Curupirina comosipes; Stuckenbergina hystrix [New Caledonia /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   Stuckenbergina (Blephariceridae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Apistomyiini, Type
   species Stuckenbergina hystrix, p. 12].

TI Description of Helicopha queenslandensis sp nov from Australia
   (Trichoptera: Helicophidae).
AU Kallsen, Marika (kjell.arne.johanson@nrm.se) 
   Johanson, Kjell Arne
SO Aquatic Insects
VL 32
IS 1
PS 25-28
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Three males and one female of Helicopha queenslandensis sp. nov. were
   collected from Bunya Mountains National Park in Queensland, Australia.
   The species is described and illustrated, and represents the fourth
   known species in the genus Helicopha in Australia and the first species
   in the genus recorded from Queensland. The three previously described
   Helicopha species are H. astia from Tasmania and New South Wales, H.
   hortena from New South Wales, and H. delamarei from Tasmania. Helicopha
   queenslandensis sp. n. is described, representing the first record of
   Helicopha from Queensland. A key to the males of Helicopha in Australia
   is provided.
C1 Kallsen, Marika; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Entomol, Stockholm,
   Sweden, Sweden.
EM kjell.arne.johanson@nrm.se
OI Johanson, Kjell Arne/0000-0002-1893-3429

DT Article
TI A review of the genus Elophila Hubner, 1822 in China (Lepidoptera:
   Crambidae: Acentropinae).
AU Chen, Fuqiang
   Wu, Chunsheng
   Xue, Dayong (xuedy@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Aquatic Insects
VL 32
IS 1
PS 35-60
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Fifteen species of the genus Elophila Hubner are recognised from China,
   including two new species described herein, namely E. radiospinula and
   E. nuda. The species E. melagynalis (Agassiz, 1978) from Fujian Province
   was a misidentification of Thysanoidma octalis Hampson, 1891 and its
   record in China is abolished. The species E. manilensis (Hampson, 1917),
   E. orientalis (Filipjev, 1933) and E. miurai Yoshiyasu, 1985 are
   reported for the first time in China. Descriptions of the genus and
   subgenera and a key to the Chinese species of Elophila are provided. The
   adults and the genital structures of all examined species are
   illustrated.
C1 Xue, Dayong; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Beijing, China, China.
EM xuedy@ioz.ac.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0424

   distribution; systematics].

   Elophila (Munroessa) radiospinula [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
   Elophila manilensis; Elophila miurai; Elophila orientalis [China /  /

TI New gastropods from Middle Jurassic geschiebe from northeastern Germany.
FT Neue Gastropoden aus Dogger-Geschieben Nordostdeutschlands.
AU Gruendel, Joachim (joachim.gruendel@lingua-pura.de) 
   Koppka, Jens
   Schneider, Steffen
SO Archiv fuer Geschiebekunde
VL 6
IS 1
PS 2-50
PD Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB 43 gastropod species are described from geschiebes (glacial erratic
   boulders) of Middle Jurassic age found in northeastern Germany. 10
   species are already known from geschiebe but the new finds are better
   preserved. 33 species are new for geschiebes. New are the genera
   Guidonopsis n. gen. and Sinuosina n. gen. and the species Amphitrochus
   erraticus n. sp., Nuartiella rara n. sp., Eligmoloxus ventricosus n. sp.
   and Kaiwarella erratica n. sp.

TI Synonyms of Ostracodes from Geschiebes III.

   Hinz-Schallreuter, Ingelore
SO Archiv fuer Geschiebekunde
VL 6
IS 1
PS 61-72
PD Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Synonyms are: Leperditia krausei STEUSLOFF,1895 and Leperditia kiesowii
   STEUSLOFF,1895, both from the same Leptaena limestone geschiebe from
   Neubrandenburg, and Macronotella elliptica KuMMEROw,1924, and possibly
   also Brevidorsa sarvi NEcKAJA,1973. In the scope of the revision of
   these species the holotypes of M. fabuliformis HESSLAND,1949 and M.
   planosalebrosa HESSLAND,1949 from the Middle Ordovician of Dalarna
   (Sweden) are refigured.

PT J

PM 20097307
DT Article
TI High-level phylogenetic analysis using developmental sequences: The
   Cambrian [dagger]Martinssonia elongata, [dagger]Musacaris gerdgeyeri
   gen. et sp. nov and their position in early crustacean evolution.
AU Haug, Joachim T. (joachim.haug@uni-ulm.de) 
   Waloszek, Dieter
   Haug, Carolin
   Maas, Andreas
SO Arthropod Structure & Development
VL 39
IS 2-3
PS 154-173
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The ontogenetic sequence of [dagger]Martinssonia elongata, a derivative
   of the stem lineage of Eucrustacea, has been re-investigated.
   Morphological and morphometric data provide a revision of the original
   description of this species. Specimens originally assigned to second and
   third developmental stages have been removed from the [dagger]M.
   elongata sequence and assigned, together with several larger specimens,
   to an entirely new species, [dagger]Musacaris gerdgeyeri gen et. sp. nov
   having a completely unsegmented body, giving the appearance of a giant
   euarthropod head larva. This is interpreted either as a hypertrophied
   larva or a late developmental stage of a neotenic species. Only the
   earliest unsegmented larvae and segmented instars of the original
   sequence are ascribed to [dagger]M. elongata. The two species are
   apparently closely related and are closer to Labrophora
   ([dagger]Phosphatocopina + Eucrustacea) than to other Cambrian '"Orsten'
   crustacean stem derivatives". The ontogenetic sequences of the two taxa
   and those of the other derivatives of the recently investigated
   labrophoran stem lineage indicate several heterochronic peramorphic
   ('adultising') events during early crustacean evolution. This is most
   evident in the development of the proximal parts of the appendages. (C)
   2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Haug, Joachim T.; Univ Ulm, Workgrp Biosystemat Documentat, Helmholtzstr
   20, Ulm, Germany, Germany.
EM joachim.haug@uni-ulm.de
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1467-8039
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Life cycle and development;
   Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Martinssonia elongata [Development / Ontogeny / reinvestigation;
   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Sweden /  / ] [Cambrian /
   Middle to Upper Cambrian / ]. 
   Musacaris [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Musacaris gerdgeyeri [Sweden /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea
OR Martinssonia elongata - Mueller & Walossek 1986 (Crustacea): [Fossil]. 
   Musacaris (Crustacea): [Gen nov, Type species Musacaris gerdgeyeri, p.
   161, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Musacaris gerdgeyeri (Crustacea): [Sp nov, Sweden, Cambrian, P. 161;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610068493
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Taxonomic-faunistic notes on the Philodromidae (Aranei) of Turkey.
AU Logunov, D.V. (dmitri.v.logunov@manchester.ac.uk) 
   Kunt, K.B.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 1
PS 11-20
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper presents taxonomic-faunistic notes on 18 species of
   Philodromidae of Turkey. Artanes is re-elevated to generic rank, with 17
   valid species to be included in it. Nine new combinations are proposed
   (all ex Philodromus): A. femurostriatus (Muster, 2009) comb.n., A.
   johani (Muster, 2009) comb.n., A. laricium (Simon, 1875) comb.n., A.
   maghrebi (Muster, 2009) comb.n., A. parietalis (Simon, 1875) comb.n., A.
   penteri (Muster, 2009) comb.n., A. pinetorum (Muster, 2009) comb.n., A.
   utotchkini (Marurik, 1991) comb.n. and A. validus (Gertsch, 1933)
   comb.n. Two species, Artanes bucaensis sp.n. ([female] from Izmir
   Province) and Thanatus nitidus sp.n. ([female] from Adiyaman and
   Gaziantep Provinces), are described as new. Four species, viz.
   Philodromus bistigma Simon, 1870, P. pulchellus Lucas, 1846, Manuals
   fabricii (Audouin, 1827) and Thanatus sabulosus (Menge, 1875), are
   recorded new to the Turkish fauna. In total, the philodromid fauna of
   Turkey is currently known to contain 37 species.

TI A survey of the East Palaearctic Lycosidae (Aranei). 5. Taxonomic notes
   on the easternmost Palaearctic Pirata species and on the genus Piratosa
   Roewer, 1960.
AU Marusik, Yuri M.
   Omelko, Mikhail M.
   Koponen, Seppo
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 1
PS 29-36
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Study of the paratypes of Pirata shibatai Tanaka, 1995 syn.n. from
   Hokkaido, Japan revealed that it is a junior synonym of P. praedo
   Kulczynski, 1885 described from Kamchatka and known throughout the whole
   of Siberia and the Russian Far East. Trochosa dybowskii Kulczynski, 1885
   syn.n. described and known only from Kamchatka is synonymized with the
   circum-Holarctic Trochosa terricola Thorell, 1856. The genus Piratosa
   Roewer, 1960 syn.n. (type species Trochosa dybowskii Kulczynski, 1885)
   is synonymized with Trochosa C.L. Koch, 1847. Two new combinations are
   established: Arctosa lawrencei (Roewer, 1960) comb.n. and A. bicoloripes
   (Roewer, 1960) comb.n. both ex. Piratosa.
C1 Marusik, Yuri M.; RAS, Inst Biol Problems N, Portovaya Str 18, Magadan,
   Russia, Russia.
RI Marusik, Yuri/D-5701-2018
OI Marusik, Yuri/0000-0002-4499-5148

   Taxonomic position

   from Piratosa, p. 35]. 
   Arctosa lawrencei - (Roewer 1960) (Araneae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Piratosa, p. 35].

   dybowskii Kulczynski 1885, p. 35].

TI A new Tenuiphantes Saaristo et Tanasevitch, 1996 from the Caucasus,

AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (and-tan@mail.ru)

U2 1
AB Tenuiphantes teberdaensis sp.n. is described from the Caucasus. Russia,
   differing from congeners by the peculiar shape of the protruding lamella

   structure in the female.

PT J
AN ZOOR14607050122
DT Article
TI On spiders from the tundra zone of the Kola Peninsula, Russia
   (Arachnida: Aranei).
AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (and-tan@mail.ru) 
   Rybalov, Leonid B.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 19
IS 1
PS 41-56
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A checklist of 105 spiders from the tundra zone of the Kola Peninsula is
   based and compiled on the original collections and on available
   literature data. Oreoneta sinuosa (Tullgren, 1955) is reported as a new
   to the Russian fauna. A new synonym is proposed: Lepthyphantes
   murmanicola Strand, 1913, syn.n. = Oryphantes angulatus (O.
   Pickard-Cambridge, 1881). Some previous misidentifications are
   rectified. Faunistic data and the distribution pattern are indicated for
   each species. For the majority of the recorded spiders, the northern
   coast of the Kola Peninsula is the northernmost point of their known
   distributions. The spider fauna of the tundra zone of the Kola Peninsula
   has a typical boreal face, and is composed of widespread or European
   boreal/polyzonal species. There are no real Arctic elements found here.
   The zonal plant communities have the fewest spider species, lack of the
   specific elements, and are comprised of boreal or ubiquitous species.
   Intrazonal and anthropogenic communities are much richer, and together
   with azonal communities serve as a shelter not only for the southern
   elements, but also for the arcto-alpine species.
C1 Tanasevitch, Andrei V.; Russian Acad Sci, Ctr Forest Ecol & Prod,
   Profsoyuznaya Str 84-32, Moscow, Russia, Russia.
EM and-tan@mail.ru
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Documentation; Publications;
   Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Aranei [Checklists /  / ] [Tundra /  / ] [Russia / Kola Peninsula / ]. 
   Oreoneta sinuosa [Russia /  / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Aranei (Araneae). 
   Oreoneta sinuosa (Araneae): [New record]. 
   Oryphantes angulatus - Pickard-Cambridge 1881 (Araneae): [Syn nov,
   Lepthyphantes murmanicola Strand 1913, p. 47].

TI [Revision of the Albian gastropods described by Nickles (1891).]
FT Revision de las nuevas especies de gasteropodos albienses descritas por
   Nickles (1891).
AU Calzada, Sebastian (almeracomas@hotmail.com) 
SO Batalleria
VL 15
PS 43-49
PD marc 2009-2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Among several fauna Nickles described as new species the following
   gastropods: Trochus vilaplanae, Solarium cortazari and Cerithium
   hornosi. They were collected in Lowermost Albian of Fontcalent
   (Alicante). After revision of topotypes new generic asignments are
   proposed as follows: Clanculus vilaplanai and Cirsocerithium hornosi.
   But Solarium cortazari is thought to be a synonym of Astele gurgitis
   Brongniart. 1822, this last species has been revised by Kollmann (2005).

   (Chaetognatha), with a description of two new species from the

VL 36
IS 2
PS 94-98

PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Russian Journal of Marine

LA Russian
U1 0

AB A brief taxonomic review of some groups of the family Sagittidae is
   presented. Keys for the identification of the currently known species of
   the genus Ferosagitta Kassatkina, 1971 are provided. Sagitta gloria
   Prado, 1961 is herein transferred to Ferosagitta as F. gloria (Prado,
   1961) comb. n. Drawings and detailed descriptions of two new species of
   Ferosagitta (F. curta sp. n. and F. longa sp. n.) from the northwestern
   Sea of Japan are provided.

DT Article
TI On the species composition of the northwestern Pacific munnopsid genera
   Eurycope and Baeonectes, with a redescription of E. ochotensis Kussakin,
   1979 (Crustacea: Isopoda).
AU Malyutina, M.V. (m_malyutina@mail.ru) 
   Golovan, O.A.
SO Biologiya Morya (Vladivostok)
VL 36
IS 2
PS 99-108
PD Mart-Aprel 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Russian Journal of Marine
   Biology.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two northwestern Pacific species of the munnopsid subfamily Eurycopinae
   [long dash] Eurycope pavlenkoi Gurjanova, 1933 and E. ochotensis
   Kussakin, 1979 [long dash] are transferred from the genus Eurycope G.O.
   Sars, 1864 to the genus Baeonectes Wilson, 1982 within this subfamily on
   the basis of the following characters: a short truncated epipod of the
   maxilliped; a broad rostrum without distinct margins; the absence of the
   distomedial lobe of article 1 of the antennula; a broad, rounded molar
   and a long condyle of the mandible; and dorsomedially fused pereonites
   5[long dash]7. Based on the above characters, it is suggested that
   Tytthocope pygmaea (G.O. Sars, 1870) from the northern Atlantic be also
   transferred to the genus Baeonectes. A redescription of B. ochotensis, a
   modified diagnosis of Baeonectes, and a new combination of the species
   of this genus are presented. A representative of the genus Baeonectes
   is, for the first time, mentioned for the Sea of Japan.
C1 Malyutina, M.V.; A.V. Zhirmunsky Institute of Marine Biology, Far East
   Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok 690041, Russia, Russia.
EM m_malyutina@mail.ru

SN 0134-3475

TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda

   record]. 
   Baeonectes ochotensis - (Kussakin 1979) (Isopoda): [Redescription, P.
   101; Comb nov, Transferred from Eurycope, p. 101]. 
   Baeonectes pavlenkoi - (Gurjanova 1933) (Isopoda): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Eurycope, p. 101; New record]. 
   Baeonectes pygmaea - (Sars 1870) (Isopoda): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Tytthocope, p. 101]. 
   Eurycope ochotensis - Kussakin 1979 (Isopoda): [Referred to, Baeonectes,
   p. 101].

   p. 101].

DT Article
TI Cryptosporidium in ferret (Mustela putorius furo) in the south of
   Brazil.
FT Cryptosporidium spp. em furao (Mustela putorius furo) no sul do Brasil.
AU da Rosa Fanfa, Vinicius
   Hillard Farret, Matheus
   da Silva, Aleksandro Schafer
   Gonzalez Monteiro, Silvia (sgmonteiro@uol.com.br) 
SO Biotemas
VL 23
IS 1
PS 225-227
PD marco 2010
PY 2010
UR http://www.biotemas.ufsc.br/volumes/v23n1.htm
AW http://www.biotemas.ufsc.br/volumes/pdf/volume231/225a227.pdf
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 2
AB The aim of this research study was to evaluate the gastrointestinal
   parasitism in ferrets (Mustela putorius furo) kept in captivity in the
   southern region of Brazil. Fecal samples of two three-year-old ferrets,
   a male and a female, were analyzed by the direct smear method, the
   centrifugal lotation technique with zinc sulfate, and tha Kinyoun
   staining method. Oocysts of Cryptosporidum sp. were observed in the
   faeces of both animals. This is the irst report of this protozoan in
   ferrets in Brazil.
C1 Gonzalez Monteiro, Silvia; Departamento de Microbiologia e
   Parasitologia, Centro de Ciencias da Saude, Universidade Federal de
   Santa Maria, Campus Universitario, Camobi - Km 9, Predio 20, sala 4232,
   CEP 97105-900, Santa Maria - RS, Brazil, Brazil.

PT J

DT Article
TI Enzymatic diversity of enzymes in the soluble fraction of adult worms
   from a Venezuelan isolate of Paragonimus sp.
FT Diversidad enzimatica de la fraccion soluble de un aislado venezolano de
   adultos Paragonimus sp.
AU Gomez Martinez, Erika (eri1578@hotmail.com) 
   Ballen, Diana
   Tulio Diaz, Marcos
   Diaz Bello, Zoraida
   Zavala-Jaspe, Reinaldo
   Alarcon de Noya, Belkisyole
   Noya, Oscar
   Cesari, Italo M.
SO Boletin de Malariologia y Salud Ambiental
VL 50
IS 1
PS 75-84
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB Paragonimus sp. is a trematode that causes chronic inflammation of the
   lung in carnivorous mammals and humans, which constitute a public health
   problem in Asian and Latin American countries. Trematodes have enzymes
   that facilitate their penetration and migration through different host
   organs to ensure their life cycle. To evaluate the enzymatic diversity
   of the soluble fraction (FSPA, 100,000 g) of a Venezuelan isolate of
   Paragonimus sp. adult worms, several enzyme determinations were
   conducted at different pH. The activities of enzymes releasing
   p-nitrophenol or p-nitroanilina from the corresponding dye-related
   synthetic peptides were assessed by interpolating absorbance (A 405 nm)
   values in the corresponding calibration curve (A 405 nm vs. nmol); on
   the other hand, absorbances of 2-naphtylamine and 2-naphtols released
   from another series of synthetic substrates were read at different
   wavelengths between 450 nm and 620 nm to assess for the activity of the
   corresponding hydrolases. Phosphohydrolase, glycosidase and peptidase
   activities were detected in FSPA,
   [beta]-N-acetyl-[beta]-D-glucosaminidase (0.55 [mu]mol/h/mg, pH 5.5) and
   cystein protease (0.4 [mu]mol/h/mg, pH 5.5) being higher than all the
   other detected activities. These activities are probably related to the
   adult worm habitat and its need for glycan and peptide degradation of
   lung secretions. These results represent the first enzymatic study done
   with a Venezuelan isolate of adult Paragonimus sp. worms collected from
   the common reservoir Didelphis marsupialis.
C1 Gomez Martinez, Erika; Univ Oriente, Parasitol Lab, Caracas, Venezuela,
   Venezuela.
EM eri1578@hotmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology
BD Biochemistry; Proteins; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites;
   Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Didelphis marsupialis [Digenean parasites / Paragonimus / Parasite
   enzymes] [Venezuela /  / ]. 
   Paragonimus [Enzymes /  / ] [Mammalian hosts / Didelphis marsupialis / ]
   [Venezuela /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Marsupials; Platyhelminths;
   Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Marsupialia, Didelphidae,
   Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Didelphis marsupialis (Didelphidae): [Host]. 
   Paragonimus (Digenea): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704030649
DA 2020-09-17
ER

TI A new species of Kenyura (Collembola: Neanuridae: Pseudachorutinae) from
   Nicaragua.
AU Palacios-Vargas, Jose G. (jgpv@hp.fciencias.unam.mx) 
   Deharveng, Louis
SO Brenesia
VL 73-74
PS 85-88
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Kenyura Salmon, 1954 from Nicaragua, Central
   America, is described and illustrated. Kenyan? nicaraguensis sp. nov. is
   similar K. porcula (Arle, 1960) from Brazil, in size and number of eyes,
   but differs in having the apical bulb of antenna simple and a reduced
   number of mandible teeth. The complete chaetotaxy of the new taxon is
   given. A key to the species of the genus and a redefinition of Kenyura
   is included.
C1 Palacios-Vargas, Jose G.; UNAM, Lab Ecol & Sistemat Microartrepodos,

PT J
AN ZOOR14705033801
DT Article
TI The Bruchidius albopubens (Pic) species-group: definition, description
   of new species and biological data (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae,
   Bruchinae).
FT Le groupe d'especes Bruchidius albopubens (Pic): definition, description
   d'especes nouvelles et donnees biologiques (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae,
   Bruchinae).
AU Delobel, Alex (delobel.alex@aliceadsl.fr) 
   Le Rue, Bruno
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 1
PS 23-29
PD Mars 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species-group Bruchidius albopubens (Pic) is created for B.
   albopubens, widespread in Africa south of the Sahara and in southern
   Asia, B. medaniensis (Decelle), until now known only from Sudan, also
   present in Kenya, as well as two new species: B. umbratus from the
   Comoros, and B. watamuensis from Kenya. These Seed Beetles seem strongly
   associated with tribe Indigoferae (Leguminosae, Fabaceae): the larva of
   B. watamuensis develops in the seeds of Indigofera trita var. subulata
   (Vahl ex Poir.) Ali, whereas that of B. albopubens feeds in the seeds of
   four Indigofera species and in those of Cyamopsis tetragonoloba (L.)
   Taub., also an Indigofereae.
C1 Delobel, Alex; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CP 50, 45 Rue Buffon, Paris,
   France, France.
EM delobel.alex@aliceadsl.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0037-928X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa; Oceanic
   islands; Indian Ocean islands

TI Contribution to the knowledge of Phasmatodea from Dominica and
   Saint-Lucia.
FT Contribution a la connaissance des Phasmatodea de Dominique et de
   Sainte-Lucie.
AU Langlois, Frederic (asper.fl@free.fr) 
   Lelong, Philippe
SO Bulletin de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 115
IS 1
PS 59-72
PD Mars 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB The list of the Phasmatodea of Dominica and Saint-Lucia is updated
   following two missions of inventory devoted to this order.
   Identification keys for adults and eggs are exposed and a new species
   from Dominica, Pseudoclonistria royi n. gen., n. sp., is described. A
   new combination about Sermyle kirbyi is proposed; the female is
   described for the first time. Distribution maps of the species on their
   respective island(s) are also presented. Two new synonymies between
   Diapherodes gigantea and D. gigantea dominicae, and between Lamponius
   guerini and L. dominicae, are established.

PS 1-10
PD March 2010

NT Unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Carboniferous ammonoid Proshumardites sp., Gastrioceras sp.,
   Agathiceras? sp., and Anthracoceras sp. are described from the
   Uzura-quarry, Shuho-Mine, Akiyoshi-dai, Southwest Japan. This ammonoid
   fauna indicates from Serpukhovian (Mississippian) to Bashkirian
   (Pennsylvanian) in age. This is the first occurrence of Anthracoceras
   sp. from Akiyoshi-dai area.

DT Article
TI Two new Early Carboniferous species of pachyporid tabulate corals from
   the Akiyoshi Limestone Group, Yamaguchi Prefecture.
AU Niko, Shuji
SO Bulletin of the Akiyoshi-Dai Museum of Natural History
VL 45
PS 11-16
PD March 2010
PY 2010
NT Unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The pachyporid tabulate corals, Gertholites antiquus sp. nov. and
   Thamnoptychia yanagidai sp. nov., are described from the upper
   Tournaisian to lower Visean (Lower Carboniferous) strata of the Akiyoshi
   Limestone Group, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Southwest Japan. The former is
   comparable with the generic type, G. curvatus (Waagen and Wentzel,
   1886), from the Upper Permian of the Salt Range and Timor, and
   represents the oldest record of Gertholites. The most closely related
   species with T. yanagidai is T. directa (Flugel, 1972) known from the
   Lower Permian of Iran. The geographic ranges of these genera are
   increased to now include Japan.
C1 Niko, Shuji; Department of Environmental Studies, Faculty of Integrated
   Arts and Sciences, Hiroshima University, 1-7-1 Kagamiyama,
   Higashihiroshima, Hiroshima 739-8521, Japan, Japan.

SN 0065-5554

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata

TI Cleistoporid tabulate corals from the Millerella yowarensis zone
   (Serpukhovian, Early Carboniferous) of the Akiyoshi Limestone Group in
   the Minami-dai area, Yamaguchi Prefecture.
AU Niko, Shuji
   Haikawa, Takehiko
SO Bulletin of the Akiyoshi-Dai Museum of Natural History
VL 45
PS 17-20
PD March 2010
PY 2010
NT Unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of cleistoporid tabulate corals, including Donetzites
   kibiensis Niko, 1999, D. verrniculatus Niko, 1999 and Pseudodonetzites
   otai gen. et sp. nov., are documented from the Millerella yowarensis
   zone (late Serpukhovian, late Early Carboniferous) of the Akiyoshi
   Limestone Group in the Minami-dai area, Mine-shi, Yamaguchi Prefecture,
   Southwest Japan. Previously named two species of Donetzites have been
   reported from the Hina Limestone, Okayama Prefecture. Diagnosis is given
   for a new genus Pseudodonetzites that differs from related genus
   Donetzites Dampel, 1940 in lacking of the spongy structure in the
   intercorallite walls.

DT Article
TI A new funnel-web spider species (Araneae: Agelenidae, Tegenaria) from
   Mercantour National Park, France.
AU Bolzern, Angelo (angelo.bolzern@arachnodet.com) 
   Herve, Christophe
SO Bulletin of the British Arachnological Society
VL 15
IS 1
PS 21-26
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During a survey of the spider fauna of the Mercantour National Park in
   the French Alps, several interesting and new taxa were found. One of
   these new taxa. Tegenaria mercantarensis n. sp. (Agelenidae) is
   described here. The new species shows distinct morphological characters
   which allow easy separation from all other Tegenaria or Malthonica
   species. The most important characters in males are the short, truncated
   embolus (a character shared with T. rlomestica, the type species of
   Tegenaria, and T. miritica), the broad. curved hammerhead-shaped
   conductor and the RTA. Distinct characters in females are the atrium
   with wide spiral copulatory openings anterior to an anchor-shaped
   sclerotised ground plate, the strongly sclerotised and irregularly
   formed "shield" around the tubular-shaped spermathecae. and the
   conspicuous anterolateral lentiform areas of the spermathecae, covered
   only by membrane.During a survey of the spider fauna of the Mercantour
   National Park in the French Alps, several interesting and new taxa were
   found. One of these new taxa. Tegenaria mercantarensis n. sp.
   (Agelenidae) is described here. The new species shows distinct
   morphological characters which allow easy separation from all other
   Tegenaria or Malthonica species. The most important characters in males
   are the short, truncated embolus (a character shared with T. rlomestica,
   the type species of Tegenaria, and T. miritica), the broad. curved
   hammerhead-shaped conductor and the RTA. Distinct characters in females
   are the atrium with wide spiral copulatory openings anterior to an
   anchor-shaped sclerotised ground plate, the strongly sclerotised and
   irregularly formed "shield" around the tubular-shaped spermathecae. and
   the conspicuous anterolateral lentiform areas of the spermathecae,
   covered only by membrane.
C1 Bolzern, Angelo; Naturhist Museum Basel, Abt Biowissensch,
   Augustinergasse 2, CH-4001 Basel, Switzerland, Switzerland.

PT J
AN ZOOR14608056896
DT Article
TI A new subspecies of mountain tanager in the Anisognathus lacrymosus
   complex from the Yariguies Mountains of Colombia.
AU Donegan, Thomas M. (tdonegan@proaves.org) 
   Avendano, Jorge Enrique
SO Bulletin of the British Ornithologists' Club
VL 130
IS 1
PS 13-32
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new subspecies of Anisognathus lacrymosus is described from Serrania
   de los Yariguies in the East Andes of Colombia. The new taxon differs in
   a combination of plumage characters, including a darker back and crown,
   from the geographically proximate subspecies A.l. tamae, A.l.
   pallididorsalis and A.l. olivaceiceps of the East and Central Andes, as
   well as, on average, having a longer tail than other East Andes
   populations. The darker plumage of the new subspecies resembles that of
   A.l. intensus of the West Andes (which also occurs in more humid
   habitats), presenting a 'leap-frog' pattern of geographic variation. The
   new subspecies is restricted to paramo and stunted Andean ridgetop
   habitats, apparently being endemic to the Yariguies massif. Analyses of
   biometrics, plumage and voice support species rank for A. (lacrymosus)
   melanogenys of the Santa Marta Mountains, as previously suggested by
   some authors. Subspecies A.l. melanops, A.l. pallididorsalis, A.l.
   yariguierum and A.l. lacrymosus represent phylogenetic species based on
   plumage, but a greater vocal sample is required to further analyse the
   rank of these and other populations.
C1 Donegan, Thomas M.; Fdn ProAves, 33 Blenheim Rd, Reading, Berks, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM tdonegan@proaves.org
SC Zoology
SN 0007-1595
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Anisognathus lacrymosus yariguierum [Colombia /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Emberizidae
OR Anisognathus lacrymosus yariguierum (Emberizidae): [Subsp nov, Colombia,
   P. 16]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14608056896
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14702010627
DT Article
TI Proposal of a new Japanese name for Dasyatis sp.
AU Furumitsu, Keisuke
   Yamaguchi, Atsuko
SO Bulletin of the Faculty of Fisheries Nagasaki University
VL 91
PS 61-63
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Dasyatis includes approximately 36 species around the world,
   and at least 8 species of which are distributed around Japan. In Ariake
   Bay, a total of 5 species of Dasyatis were identified based on our
   periodic studies to clarify the elasmobranch fauna since 2001. In
   addition, an undescribed species of Dasyatis was identified which is
   characterized by a unique combination of morphological characters. We
   also collected specimens of Dasyatis sp. from western coastal areas of
   Kyushu. In this paper, we propose a new Japanese name "Ariake-akaei" for
   Dasyatis sp. to avoid taxonomic confusion.
SC Zoology
SN 0547-1427

DT Article
TI Cocotropus izuensis, a New Species of Velvetfish (Teleostei:
   Aploactinidae) from Japan.
AU Imamura, Hisashi (imamura@fish.hokudai.ac.jp) 
   Aizawa, Masahiro
   Shinohara, Gento
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 1-7
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of aploactinid, Cocotropus izuensis, is described based on
   8 secimens (25.2-47.3 mm in standard length) collected from the Izu
   Peninsula, Shizuoka Prefecture, and Chiba Prefecture, Japan. The new
   species differs from 13 valid species of Cocotrapus in having the
   following combination of characters: 12 dorsal-fin spines, 7 segmented
   lower caudal-fin rays, 26 vertebrae, 5 preopercular spines, upper jaw
   length equal to or a little shorter than the lachrymal length, no
   distinct fleshy papillae on posterior portion of upper jaw, no vomerine
   teeth, first lower jaw sensory pores on both sides fused, anterior
   position of isthmus well beyond fifth lower jaw sensory pore, 4 dorsal
   spines anterior to third neural spine, and interneural space between
   seventh and eighth neural spines without dorsal-fin spine proximal
   pterygiophores.
C1 Imamura, Hisashi; Hokkaido Univ Museum, Fisheries Sci Ctr, 3-1-1 Minato
   Cho, Hakodate, Hokkaido, Japan, Japan.

TI A Review of Malthopsis jordani Gilbert, 1905, with Description of a New
   Batfish from the Indo-Pacific Ocean (Lophiiformes: Ogcocephalidae).
AU Ho, Hsuan-Ching (ogcoho@gmail.com) 
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 9-19
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Malthopsis jordani Gilbert, 1905 was described from the Hawaiian Islands
   a: id subsequently recorded from the western Pacific. A review of the
   species is provided. Examination of all known specimens of this species
   revealed that M. jordani is endemic to the Hawaiian Is ands and
   specimens outside the range represent a new species. Malthopsis gigas
   sp. nov., previously misidentified as M. jordani, is described from 111
   specimens widely distributed in the Indo-Pacific Ocean. The new species
   differs from its congeners in having a relatively strong and long
   rostrum ([overhead single bar]x=8.6% SL); body heavily covered with
   strong conical bucklers, with numerous small hi bucklers densely
   covering the space between principal bucklers on the dorsal surface; and
   the reclined anal fin that extends beyond the caudal fin base. The new
   species is also the largest member of the genus, reaching size up to
   136.4 mm SL.

   Keelung, Taiwan, Taiwan.

TI A New Species of the Flathead Genus Inegocia (Teleostei:
   Platycephalidae) from East Asia.
AU Imamura, Hisashi (imamura@fish.hokudai.ac.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 21-29
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of platycephalid, Inegocia ochiaii, is described based on
   specimens, ranging from 47.2-444.0 mm SL, collected from southern Japan
   and Taiwan. Inegocia ochiaii differs from other platycephalids in having
   the following combination of characters: I + VIII first dorsal-fin rays,
   usually 11 second dorsal and anal-fin rays, 63-76 oblique body scale
   rows slanting downward and backward above the lateral line, a long snout
   (31.7-34.9% HL), a long and branched iris lappet, the posterior margin
   of the orbit lacking distinct pit, the suborbital ridge with 2 spines
   (preorbital spine absent), a single large interopercular flap present,
   sensory tubes from the suborbitals and preopercle not covering cheek
   region, and scales anteriorly on the lateral line with either single
   posterior opening or with 2 openings and scales posteriorly on the
   lateral line with 2 openings.

DT Article
TI Three New Species of the Ptereleotrid Fish Genus Parioglossus
   (Perciformes: Gobioidei) from Japan, Palau and India.
AU Suzuki, Toshiyuki (trimma-toshiyuki@hop.ocn.ne.jp) 
   Yonezawa, Toshihiko
   Sakaue, Jiro
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 31-48
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the ptereleotrid fish genus Parioglossus. P
   caeruleolineatus, P soma and P winterbottomi are described based on
   specimens from Japan. Palau and India. Parioglossus caeruleolineatus (8
   specimens, 20.4-27.1 mm SL, Amami-oshima Island, Japan) differs from all
   other congeners in having a moderately oblique mouth at an angle of
   51-58[degree] (average 55[degree]) to longitudinal axis of body, and a
   bright blue stripe running from nape to dorsum of caudal peduncle in
   male when fresh or alive. Parioglossus senoui (8 specimens, 17.5-22.9 mm
   SL, Babeldaob Island, Palau, and Iriomote-jima Island, Japan) differs
   from all other congeners in having three segmented pelvic-fin rays.
   Parioglossus winterbottomi (2 specimens, 31.0 and 37.8 mm SL, West
   Bengal, India) differs from all other congeners in having cheek and
   opercular scales, and the first dorsal fin shaped like a horse's mane in
   males. A revised key to the species of Parioglossus is provided.
C1 Suzuki, Toshiyuki; Amagasaki Kita Senior High Sch, 5-40-1

TI Myopsaron nelsoni, a New Genus and Species of Sandburrowers
   (Perciformes: Trichonotidae: Creediinae) from the Ogasawara Islands,
   Japan.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 49-66
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of the trichonotid subfamily Creediinae,
   Myopsaron nelsoni, is described based on 43 specimens, including 20 type
   specimens (22.1-36.3 mm if standard length), collected by sledge nets at
   the depths of 55-99 m off southern Chichi-jiroa Island, Ogasawara
   Islands, Japan. It is readily distinguished from the other genera of the
   subfamily by having some unique, apparently autapomorphic, features,
   e.g., the globular fleshy extension at the tip of upper jaw,
   discontinuous lateral line on body, higher number of precaudal vertebrae
   than caudal vertebrae (24-26+18-21=43-45 vertebrae), and edentate
   premaxilla. Myopsaron is highly specialized, but, as well as Creedia, it
   appears to be nested within the basal creediines since it lacks several
   specializations found in all other creediines exclusive of the most
   primitive member, Schizochirus.
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Taito Ku, 3-10-10 Shitaya,
   Tokyo, Japan, Japan.
EM kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp

   Taxonomic implications]. 
   Myopsaron nelsoni [North Pacific / Bonin Islands / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Perciformes, Creediidae, Trichonotidae

DT Article
TI Ancistrogobius, a New Cheek-spine Goby Genus from the West Pacific and
   Red Sea, with Descriptions of Four New Species (Perciformes: Gobiidae:
   Gobiinae).
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
   Yoshino, Tetsuo
   Allen, Gerald R.
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 67-87
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new gobiid fish genus, Ancistrogobius, is described based on 4 new
   species (A. dipus, A. squamiceps, A. yanoi, and A. yoshigoui) from the
   western Pacific and Red Sea. Ancistrogobius is unique within the gobiid
   subfamily Gobiinae in having a short, ventrally directed bony spine-like
   projection at the posterior margin of the preopercle. Within the genus,
   A. dipus n. sp. (8 type specimens, 31.6-42.4 mm SL) is unique in having
   a separated pelvic fin with a rudimentary connecting membrane between
   the innermost rays and no frenum (vs. pelvic fins unitec medially with a
   well-developed connecting membrane and frenum in the other species).
   Ancistrogobius squamiceps n. sp. (2 type specimens, 29.8-50.5 mm SL)
   differs from congeners in having scales on most of the nape and 12
   predorsal scales (vs. nape almost naked, typically without scales on
   predorsal midline) and a scale patch on the dorsal part of the operculum
   (vs. head naked). Of the remaining 2 new species, A. yanoi n. sp. (14
   type and 2 non-type specimens, 16.9-36.8 mm SL) is chiefly distinguished
   from the other, A. yoshigoui n. sp. (14 type specimens, 26.1-40.6 mm
   SL), in having an elongate and filamentous third spine in the first
   dorsal fin (vs. no filamentous spines in the latter species). Almost all
   of the examined specimens of this genus were collected from the western
   Pacific, exclusive of 2 Red Sea specimens, provisionally identified as
   A. yanoi. Ancistrogobius: is a bottom-dwelling goby genus, found on
   sandy or sandy-mud bottoms with dead-coral rubble in protected bays
   (0-50 m depths), and is not commensal with other marine organism:;.
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Taito Ku, 3-10-10 Shitaya,
   Tokyo, Japan, Japan.
EM kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp

   Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

TI Hetereleotris exilis, a New Goby (Teleostei, Perciformes, Gobiidae) from
   the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 89-95
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the gobiid fish. Hetereleatris exilis, is described
   based on a single female specimen (22.1 mm SL) collected at the depth of
   53 m of off Nagan'nu Island, Okinawa Group of the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
   It is unique within the genus in having very slender body (depth at
   anal-fin Origin 11.9% of standard length), and characterized by the
   following: VI-I, 12 dorsal-fin rays; I, II anal-fin rays; 16
   pectoral-fin rays; I, 5 pelvic-fin rays; innermost (=fifth) segmented
   pelvic-fin ray unbranched, long, subequal to preceding ray in length;
   scales cycloid, restricted on posterior part of body (ca. 14-15
   longitudinal scales); no head sensory-canal pores.

TI Gobiopsis namnas, a New Deep-dwelling Goby (Teleostei: Perciformes:
   Gobiidae: Gobiinae) from Japan.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 97-106
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the gobiid fish, Gobiopsis namnas, is described based
   on 8 soecimens (2 males and 6 females, 20.2-35.2 mm SL) trawled at the
   depth of 101 m of oft Toi-misaki Point, Miyazaki of Kyushu, Japan. G.
   namnas has depressed head and characteristic arrangement of cutaneous
   ridges with sensory papillae on cheek like the other species of
   Gobiopsis, but unique within the genus in having: no head barbels (vs.
   present in the congeners); 8-9 segmented dorsal-fin rays (vs. typically
   10-12); 24-26 longitudinal scales (vs. more than 30); 8-9 transverse
   scales from anal-fin base upward and forward to base of dorsal fin (vs.
   12-26); and scales on upper part of cheek and operculum (vs. absent).
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Taito Ku, 3-10-10 Shitaya,

DT Article
TI Phoxacromion kaneharai, a New Genus and Species of Gobiid Fish
   (Teleostei: Perciformes: Gobiidae) from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
   Suzuki, Toshiyuki
   Senou, Hiroshi
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 107-117
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new marine goby genus and species of the gobiid subfamily Gobiinte,
   Phoxacromion kaneharai, is described based on 7 specimens (15.9-21.9 mm
   SL) from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan. It is unique amongst the gobiine
   genera in having the expanded lateral wing of the cleithrum with a
   distinct, anterolaterally-directed triangular mid-lateral margin.
   Phoxacromion is similar to Palutrus in general morphology, but
   distinguished from the latter in having the following features
   (including the cleithral modification previously noted): no distinct
   mental frenurn (vs. present in Palutrus); a short transverse sensory
   papillae row on middle of cheek (vs. replaced by a single papilla only);
   9 and 8 segmented dorsal and anal-fin rays (vs. 7-8 and 6-7,
   respectively); more slender body (body depth at anal-fin origin
   15.0-16.6% of SL vs. more than 17.0%). A putative close affinity of
   Phoxacromion with Palutrus and/or Drombus (particularly the slender
   nominal species D. simulus) is suggested. P. kaneharai is A secretive
   bottom dweller, found under rubbles on sandy or gravel bottoms in
   shallow protected bays.
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Taito Ku, 3-10-10 Shitaya,
   Tokyo, Japan, Japan.
EM kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp

SN 1881-9052

   Pacific Ocean

   Perciformes, Gobiidae

TI Glossanodon kotakamaru, a New Argentine Fish from Southern Japan
   (Protacanthopterygii: Argentinidae).
AU Endo, Hiromitsu (endoh@kochi-u.ac.jp) 
   Nashida, Kazuya
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
SU Suppl 4
PS 119-127
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of argentinid, Glossanodon kotakamaru, is described on the
   basis of 11 specimens (57-125 mm SL) from Tosa Bay and off Amami Oshima
   Island, southern Japan. The new species differs from its congeners in
   having the following combination of characters: dorsal-fin rays 12-13;
   anal-fin rays 11-13; pectoral-fin rays 21-23; pelvic-fin rays 13-14;
   branchiostegal rays 5; gill-rakers on first arch 37-40; vertebrae 49-50;
   2-4 small conical teeth on middle of lower jaws and 1-3 on tongue;
   predorsal length 48-49% SL, prepectoral length 29-30% SL, prepelvic
   length 55-56% SL; caudal peduncle depth 5.5-5.9% SL; head length 29-30%
   SL; eye diameter 32-33% HL; snout length 33% HL; maxillary depth 12% HL
   (in 3 larger specimens); anus immediately anterior to anal-fin origin; a
   longitudinal black stripe dorsal to lateral line; isthmus to thorax
   pigmented. The new species is a benthopelagic dweller on muddy and sandy
   bottoms in depths of about 150-300 m.
C1 Endo, Hiromitsu; Kochi Univ, Marine Biol Lab, 2-5-1 Akebono Cho, Kochi,
   Japan, Japan.

DT Article
TI Redefinition and proposal of the new standard Japanese name for
   Rhinogobius sp. or morphotype "Shimahire" (Perciformes, Gobiidae).
AU Suzuki, Toshiyuki (trimma-toshiyuki@hop.ocn.ne.jp) 
   Mukai, Takahiko
   Yoshigou, Hidenori
   Oseko, Naoharu
   Tyon, Darsu
SO Bulletin of the Osaka Museum of Natural History
VL 64
PS 1-14
PD March 2010
PY 2010
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rhinogobius sp. OR morphotype "Shimahire" was first reported from a
   river of Hyogo Prefecture, southwestern part of Honshu, Japan.
   Subsequent studies revealed that it was genetically and ecologically
   differed from all other morphotypes of Rhinogobius sp. OR, as well as
   all other Rhinogobius species in Japan. Nevertheless, comprehensive
   morphological studies of the morphotype "Shimahire" have never been
   done. We thus compared the morphological details between the morphotype
   "Shimahire" and the other Japanese species of Rhinogobius, based on 300
   good-quality images of Rhinogobius sp. OR (including morphotype
   "Shimahire" ) and some other look-alike species collected from Japan. As
   a result, the "Simahire" morphotype is clearly distinguished from the
   others in shape of first dorsal fin, coloration, squamation, and
   sensory-canal arrangement on head. In this paper, we recognized the
   morphotype "Shimahire" as a distinct and fifteenth Japanese species of
   Rhinogobius (as Rhinogobius sp. BF), and described its morphology in
   detail. For suitable protection, the new standard Japanese name,
   Shimahire-yoshinobori, is also proposed for this species. The scientific
   name of this species is not able to be identified here, because the
   taxonomy of Rhinogobius is currently confused worldwide.
C1 Suzuki, Toshiyuki; Amagasaki-kita Senior High School, Tsukaguchimachi,
   Amagasaki, Hyogo 661-0002, Japan, Japan.
EM trimma-toshiyuki@hop.ocn.ne.jp
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0078-6675
BD Systematics; Animals and man; Evolution; Variation; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   [Morphological variation / Morphotype characterization / ] [Japan /  /

   Neotropical area. We describe three new species in the Neotropical

DT Article
TI A new whitefish from the early Quaternary of Bluefish Basin, Yukon
   Territory, Canada, and its paleoenvironmental implications.
AU Cumbaa, Stephen (scumbaa@mus-nature.ca) 
   Lauriol, Bernard
   Alfonso, Noel
   Ross, Martin
   Mott, Robert
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 47
IS 3
PS 221-235
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A nearly complete fossil of a whitefish, Coregonus beringiaensis sp.
   nov. (Salmoniformes: Salmonidae: Coregoninae), the oldest known record
   of the genus, is described from Ch'ijee's Bluff along the Porcupine
   River, Bluefish Basin, Yukon Territory. The new species is closest to
   but distinct from species within the Coregonus clupeaformis complex,
   especially in its low lateral line scale count, quadrate with an
   extensive canal and pore complex, Y-shaped lachrymal, and a unique
   combination of counts and measurements of fins, scales, and body
   proportions. The stratigraphic position of the source concretionary
   layer, at the base of unit 3, a lacustrine unit, is well below a
   magnetically reversed interval thought to represent at least the upper
   part of the Matuyama Chron. The specimen was found above ice-wedge
   pseudomorphs thought to be the first sign of the onset of cold
   temperatures in the early Quaternary. The fossil is older than 0.79 Ma
   and probably younger than 2.58 Ma. Palynomorphs in the concretion
   suggest an open shrub-tundra environment and a climate colder than that
   of the present, similar to conditions prevailing at or above the tree
   line, and a good fit for preglacial conditions in the early Quaternary.
   Sedimentary and geochemical analyses suggest that fossilization occurred
   in an environment characterized by fine sedimentation in a cold,
   reducing milieu with a pH of [approximately]7.5. Alternatively, these
   conditions may reflect the postdepositional or early diagenetic
   environment. The lake in which the whitefish lived was possibly part of
   a hydrographic basin draining toward the Arctic Ocean.
C1 Cumbaa, Stephen; Canadian Museum Nat, POB 3443,Stn D, Ottawa, ON,
   Canada, Canada.
EM scumbaa@mus-nature.ca
RI Ross, Martin/A-2501-2011
OI Ross, Martin/0000-0002-6029-3445; Alfonso, Noel/0000-0003-3716-7704
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0008-4077
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Coregonus [Yukon Territory / Porcupine River, Ch'ijee's Bluff / new
   record] [Pleistocene / Gelasian / ]. 
   Coregonus beringiaensis [Yukon Territory /  / new species] [Pleistocene
   /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Salmoniformes, Salmonidae

TI A REVIEW OF CALIFORNIA MARGARINOTUS MARSEUL (COLEOPTERA: HISTERIDAE:
   HISTERINAE: HISTERINI), WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF TWO NEW SPECIES.
AU Caterino, Michael S. (mcaterino@sbnature2.org) 
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 64
IS 1
PS 1-12
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eleven species of the genus Margarinotus Marseul (Histeridae:
   Histerinae: Histerini) are known to occur in California. One of these,
   Margarinotus merdarius (Hoffmann) is adventive, and two others,
   Margarinotus ephemeralis Caterino, new species and Margarinotus
   thomomysi Caterino, new species are described here for the first time.
   The first of these is closely related to Margarinotus remotus (LeConte),
   and the second to Margarinotus fenderi Wenzel. Both of the new species
   are restricted to the nests of burrowing rodents, Spermophilus Cuvier
   and Thomomys Wied-Neuwied, respectively, and help indicate that the
   arthropod fauna of such niches is still inadequately documented.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF REICHENBACHIA LEACH (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE:
   PSELAPHINAE) FROM GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK, USA.
AU Carlton, Christopher E. (ccarlt@lsu.edu)

IS 1
PS 39-41
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Reichenbachia parkeri Carlton, new species is described based on three
   male specimens from a single Malaise trap in Cades Cove, Great Smoky
   Mountains National Park. The species differs from all other North
   American members of the genus in the form of the aedeagus. It is found
   sympatrically with Reichenbachia hardyi Park in an area where habitats
   favorable to members of the genus occur.

TI DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES OF SCARITES FABRICIUS (COLEOPTERA:
   CARABIDAE) FROM FLORIDA.
AU Bousquet, Yves (yves.bousquet@agr.gc.ca) 
   Skelley, Paul E.
SO Coleopterists Bulletin
VL 64
IS 1
PS 45-49
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe a new species in the genus Scarites Fabricius, S. stenops
   Bousquet and Skelley, from one specimen collected in Florida. The adult
   differs from those of other Nearctic species by the very small, flat
   eyes, the extensive pustulate area at the elytral base, and the markedly
   convex elytral interval 7 behind the humerus. Scarites texanus Chaudoir
   is here synonymized under S. subterraneus Fabricius, new synonymy,
   validating the synonymy proposed in an earlier unpublished work, and
   Scarites vieinus Chaudoir, previously considered a junior synonym of S.
   quadriceps Chaudoir, is revalidated (revised status). We include an
   updated key to all known Scarites species found in North America, north
   of Mexico.

EM yves.bousquet@agr.gc.ca

PT J
AN ZOOR14608051380
PM 20374940
DT Article
TI The Australian fresh water isopod (Phreatoicidea: Isopoda) allows
   insights into the early mitogenomic evolution of isopods.
AU Kilpert, Fabian (tkilpert@evolution.uni-bonn.de) 
   Podsiadlowski, Lars
SO Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology D-Genomics & Proteomics
VL 5
IS 1
PS 36-44
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 11
AB The complete mitochondrial (mt) genome sequence of the Australian fresh
   water isopod Eophreatoicus sp.-14 has been determined. The new species
   is a member of the taxon Phreatoicidea, a clade of particular interest,
   as it is often regarded as the sister group to all other Isopoda.
   Although the overall genome organization of Eophreatoicus sp.-14
   conforms to the typical state of Metazoa-it is a circular ring of DNA
   hosting the usual 37 genes and one major non-coding region-it bears a
   number of derived characters that fall within the scope of "genome
   morphology". Earlier studies have indicated that the isopod
   mitochondrial gene order is not as conserved as that of other
   crustaceans. Indeed, the mt genome of Eophreatoicus sp.-14 shows an
   inversion of seven genes (including cox1), which is as far as we know
   unique. Even more interesting is the derived arrangement of nad1,
   trnL(CUN), rrnS, control region, cob, trnT, nad5 and trnF that is shared
   by nearly all available isopod mt genomes. A striking feature is the
   close proximity of the rearranged genes to the mt control region.
   Inferable gene translocation events are, however. more suitable to trace
   the evolution of mt genomes. Genes like nad1/trnL(CUN) and nad5/trnF,
   which retained their adjacent position after being rearranged, were most
   likely translocated together. A very good example for the need to
   understand the mechanisms of translocations is the remolding of
   trnL(UUR) to trnL(CUN). Both tRNA genes are adjacent and have a high
   sequence similarity, probably the result of a gene duplication and
   subsequent anticodon mutation. Modified secondary structures were found
   in three tRNAs of Eophreatoicus sp.-14, which are all characterized by
   the loss of the DHU-arm. This is common to crustaceans for tRNA
   Serine(AGY), while the arm-loss in tRNA Cysteine within Malacostraca is
   only shared by other isopods. Modification of the third tRNA,
   Isoleucine, is not known from any other related species. Nucleotide
   frequencies of genes have been found to be indirectly correlated to the
   orientation of the mitochondrial replication process. In Eophreatoicus
   sp.-14 and in other Isopoda the associated nucleotide bias is inversed
   to the state of other Malacostraca. This is a strong indication for an
   inversion of the control region that most likely evolved in the isopod
   ancestor. [copyright] 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
C1 Kilpert, Fabian; Univ Bonn, Inst Evolutionary Biol & Ecol, Immenburg 1,
   Bonn, Germany, Germany.
EM tkilpert@evolution.uni-bonn.de
RI Podsiadlowski, Lars/B-2796-2008
OI Podsiadlowski, Lars/0000-0001-7786-8930
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1744-117X
BD Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Eophreatoicus [Nucleic acids / Mitochondrial genome sequence / ]
   [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Evolution /  / ] [Northern Territory /  / ].
   
   Isopoda [Nucleic acids / Mitochondrial genome sequence / ] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ] [Evolution /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Isopoda (Peracarida). 
   Eophreatoicus (Isopoda). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14608051380
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14610067594
PM 20338542
DT Article
TI Sussemionus, a new subgenus of Equus (Perissodactyla, Mammalia).
AU Eisenmann, Vera (vera@mnhn.fr) 
SO Comptes Rendus Biologies
VL 333
IS 3
PS 235-240
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new subgenus of Equus, Sussemionus, is defined by peculiar dental
   characters so far unknown, or exceptional in late Pleistocene and extant
   Equus; it was in consequence assumed to be restricted to the early and
   middle Pleistocene. During that period, it was highly successful,
   ranging from North America to Ethiopia, and included dry-adapted (E.
   granatensis-like) and more humid-adapted (E. coliemensis-like) species.
   Recent molecular and osteological analyses concurred to prove its
   survival until ca 45 KYBP in Khakassia, southwest Siberia, Russia.
   [copyright]2009 Academie des sciences. Published by Elsevier Masson SAS.
   All rights reserved.

DT Article
TI Gymnocranius oblongus, a new large-eye bream species from New Caledonia
   (Teleostei: Lethrinidae).
AU Borsa, Philippe (philippe.borsa@ird.fr) 
   Bearez, Philippe
   Chen, Wei-Jen
SO Comptes Rendus Biologies
VL 333
IS 3
PS 241-247
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Gymnocranius oblongus is described as a new species of the subfamily
   Monotaxinae (Sparoidea: Lethrinidae), a group of commercially important
   fishes distributed throughout the Indo-West Pacific, from six specimens
   collected in New Caledonia. It is characterized by an oblong, fusiform
   body, slightly rounded snout, elongate tail with rounded tips and
   sub-horizontal, wavy blue lines or dashes on snout and cheeks. It is
   distinct from sympatric G. grandoculis by a more slender body which is
   also more symmetrical dorsoventrally and a more elongated caudal fin.
   Both mitochondrial-DNA and nuclear-DNA markers provide a genetic basis
   to the distinction of G. oblongus from G. grandoculis. [contains]2010
   Academie des sciences. Published by Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights
   reserved.

   Montpellier, France, France.

TI A new relictual buthid scorpion from the region of the Great Rift Valley
   in Kenya (Scorpiones, Buthidae).
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   Duhem, Bernard
   Cloudsley-Thompson, John L.
SO Comptes Rendus Biologies
VL 333
IS 3
PS 280-285
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB A new genus and species of peri-Saharian buthid scorpion is described on
   the basis of single specimen collected in the Great Rift Valley, North
   of Kenya. This new scorpion taxon represents yet another endemic relict
   element for the faunas of the peri-Saharian regions. Comments are also
   included on the evolution of the Sahara and peri-Saharian regions and
   its possible consequences on the distribution of the extant scorpion
   fauna. [copyright]2010 Academie des sciences. Published by Elsevier
   Masson SAS. All rights reserved.

PT J
AN ZOOR14608052401
PM 20099027
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Swimming speed alteration of Artemia sp and Brachionus plicatilis as a
   sub-lethal behavioural end-point for ecotoxicological surveys.
AU Garaventa, Francesca (francesca.garaventa@ismar.cnr.it) 
   Gambardella, Chiara
   Di Fino, Alessio
   Pittore, Massimiliano
   Faimali, Marco
SO Ecotoxicology
VL 19
IS 3
PS 512-519
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 48
AB In this study, we investigated the possibility to improve a new
   behavioural bioassay (Swimming Speed Alteration test-SSA test) using
   larvae of marine cyst-forming organisms: e.g. the brine shrimp Artemia
   sp. and the rotifer Brachionus plicatilis. Swimming speed was
   investigated as a behavioural end-point for application in ecotoxicology
   studies. A first experiment to analyse the linear swimming speed of the
   two organisms was performed to verify the applicability of the
   video-camera tracking system, here referred to as Swimming Behavioural
   Recorder (SBR). A second experiment was performed, exposing organisms to
   different toxic compounds (zinc pyrithione, Macrotrol[registered
   trademark] MT-200, and Eserine). Swimming speed alteration was analyzed
   together with mortality. The results of the first experiment indicate
   that SBR is a suitable tool to detect linear swimming speed of the two
   organisms, since the values have been obtained in accordance with other
   studies using the same organisms (3.05 mm s-1 for Artemia sp. and 0.62
   mm s-1 for B. plicatilis). Toxicity test results clearly indicate that
   swimming speed of Artemia sp. and B. plicatilis is a valid behavioural
   end-point to detect stress at sub-lethal toxic substance concentrations.
   Indeed, alterations in swimming speed have been detected at toxic
   compound concentrations as low as less then 0.1-5% of their LC50 values.
   In conclusion, the SSA test with B. plicatilis and Artemia sp. can be a
   good behavioural integrated output for application in marine
   ecotoxicology and environmental monitoring programs.
C1 Garaventa, Francesca; CNR, Inst Marine Sci, Via Marini 6, Genoa, Italy,
   Italy.
EM francesca.garaventa@ismar.cnr.it
RI Pittore, Massimiliano/F-5543-2013; Faimali, Marco/B-7191-2008; CNR,
   Ismar/P-1247-2014
OI Pittore, Massimiliano/0000-0003-4940-3444; CNR,
   Ismar/0000-0001-5351-1486; Faimali, Marco/0000-0001-5558-3555
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0963-9292
BD Animals and man; Techniques; Biochemical techniques; Locomotion;
   Habitat; Pollution; Abiotic factors
DE Artemia; Brachionus plicatilis [Animals as tools / Ecotoxicology &
   environmental monitoring / ] [Assay techniques / Swimming speed as
   behavioural ecotoxicology assay / ] [Swimming /  / ] [Freshwater habitat
   /  / ] [Chemical pollution /  / ] [Chemical factors / Toxic compounds /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Rotifers
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Branchiopoda, Anostraca, Rotifera
OR Artemia (Anostraca). 
   Brachionus plicatilis (Rotifera).

TI Notes on the pernyi-species group of the genus Antheraea Huebner, 1819
   ("1816") with descriptions of new taxa (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Einige Anmerkungen zur pernyi-Gruppe der Gattung Antheraea Huebner, 1819
   ("1816") mit Beschreibung neuer Arten (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Paukstadt, Ulrich
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 2
PS 5-12
PD Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of the genus Antheraea Hubner, 1819 ("1816")
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae) are described and figured: Antheraea
   (Antheraea) vietnamensis n. sp. from Vietnam (type locality (TL); also
   Laos, Thailand and Myanmar), A. (A.) pahangensis n. sp. from West
   Malaysia (Pahang state) and A. (A.) jawabaratensis n. sp. from the
   island of Java (Jawa Barat province, Indonesia). The holotype
   [male][male] of A. (A.) vietnamensis n. sp. andA. (A.) pahangensis n.
   sp., ex coll. Ronald Brechlin, Pasewalk, are deposited in coll. Museum
   Witt, Munich (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will
   be included in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany.
   The holotype [male] of A. (A.) jawabaratensis n. sp., ex coll. Laela H.
   Paukstadt, Wilhelmshaven, will be deposited in Museum Zoologicum
   Bogoriense (MZB) (Bogor, Cibinong, Java, Indonesia). The female of this
   last species remains unknown. Within the genus, the new species belong
   to the pemyi-species group (sensu Nassig 1991 and Paukstadt et al.
   2000a). A check list of this group is given.

TI New taxa of the genus Syntherata Maassen, 1873 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Neue Taxa der Gattung Syntherata Maassen, 1873 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 2
PS 13-22
PD Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten new taxa of the genus Syntherata Maassen, 1873 (Lepidoptera:
   Satumiidae) are described and figured: S. arfakiana n. sp., S. cernyi n.
   sp., S. lagariana n. sp., S. parvoantennata n. sp., S. minoris n. sp.,
   S. papuensis n. sp., S. okapiana n. sp., S. engaiana n. sp. and S.
   rudloffi n. sp. (all from the island of New Guinea) and S. godeffroyii
   michaschaarschmidti n. ssp. (from New Hanover and New Ireland, New
   Ireland province, Papua New Guinea). All holotype [male][male] ex coll.
   Ronald Brechlin, Pasewalk, are deposited in coll. Museum Witt, Munich
   (Germany), which later, together with this collection, will be included
   in Zoologische Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. In addition,
   Antheraea (Antheraea) cernyi Brechlin, 2002 syn. nov. is shown to be
   only a colour form of A. (A.) andamana Moore, 1877 and is therefore
   synonymized with this species.

TI Rhodoprasina koerferi n. sp., a new sphingid from Bhutan (Lepidoptera:
   Sphingidae).
FT Rhodoprasina koerferi n. sp., eine neue Sphingide aus Bhutan
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 3
IS 2
PS 23-26
PD Maerz 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Rhodoprasina Rothschild & Jordan, 1903
   (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae) from Bhutan is described and figured:
   Rhodoprasina koerferi n. sp. The holotype [male] (ex coll. Ronald
   Brechlin, Pasewalk) is deposited in coll. Museum Witt, Munich (Germany),
   which later, together with this collection, will be included in
   Zoologische Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. Within the genus,
   R. koerferi most closely resembles R. corrigenda Kitching & Cadiou, 1996
   (in Kitching & Brechlin 1996) and R. viksinjaevi Brechlin, 2004, but can
   be distinguished by several external characters as well as in the male
   genitalia morphology. The female and preimaginal instars of the new
   species are unknown.

DT Article
TI Revision of the taxonomic status of members of the Charaxes acraeoides
   group (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae) ; integrative approach combining
   morphology, biogeography and DNA barcoding.
FT Revision du statut des membres du groupe de Charaxes acraeoides, Druce
   1908 ; approche integrant morphologie, biogeographie et code barre ADN
   (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae).
AU Vingerhoedt, Eric
   Zakharov, Evgeny
   Rougerie, Rodolphe
   Bouyer, Thierry
SO Entomologia Africana
VL 15
IS 1
PS 36-48
PD mars 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on a broad geographical sampling of taxa within the Charaxes
   acraeoides group, the integrative study of morphology and DNA barcodes
   brings new insight into the taxonomic divisions of these butterflies. We
   propose herein an update of the status of the existing species and
   sub-species. New evidence suggests that the West African Charaxes
   fournierae jolybouyeri should be raised to the species level. In Central
   Africa, although genetic data reveal a consistent but very slight
   divergence between an occidental and an oriental lineage of C.
   fournierae, they do not support the two currently recognized oriental
   subspecies. Considering morphology and geographical distribution, we
   propose that the Kigezi (Uganda) endemic subspecies - C. fournierae
   kigeziensis - should be treated as a synonym of the nominal subspecies,
   whereas the Rwandese subspecies - C. fournierae vandenberghei - should
   be maintained.
C1 Vingerhoedt, Eric; 5 rue de la Goffe, B-4130 Esneux, Belgium, Belgium.
RI Rougerie, Rodolphe/D-2930-2009
OI Rougerie, Rodolphe/0000-0003-0937-2815

PT J
AN ZOOR14709067279
DT Article
TI C.V. RILEY'S LOST APHIDS: SIPHONOPHORA FRAGARIAE VAR. IMMACULATA AND
   APHIS RAPAE VAR. LAEVIGATA (HEMIPTERA: APHIDIDAE).
AU Favret, Colin (ColinFavret@AphidNet.org) 
   Miller, Gary L.
SO Entomological News
VL 121
IS 2
PS 200-205
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The syntypes of Siphonophora fragariae var. immaculata Riley were
   rediscovered in the aphid collection of the United States of America
   National Museum of Natural History. The name (S. fragariae immaculata)
   previously being largely lost and forgotten, we here establish it as the
   senior synonym of Macrosiphum euphorbiae (Thomas). Reversal of
   precedence can be validated, however, and we establish S. fragariae
   immaculata as a nomen oblitum and M. euphorbiae a nomen protection with
   respect to each other. In uncovering the original description of the
   Riley species, we also found a description of Aphis rapae var. laevigata
   Riley. We have not found A. rapae laevigata anywhere else in the
   literature nor have we found any type specimens. Based on Riley's
   succinct description and host plant identity, we consider it a nomen
   dubium synonym of Myzus persicae (Sulzer). Because the short articles
   publishing the two aphid names have been missing from taxonomists'
   libraries, they are transcribed in their entirety.
C1 Favret, Colin; AphidNet LLC, 18901 Tributary Ln, Gaithersburg, MD, USA,
   USA.
EM ColinFavret@AphidNet.org
RI Favret, Colin/F-7726-2012
OI Favret, Colin/0000-0001-6243-3184
SC Zoology
SN 0013-872X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Available name; Unavailable name
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Aphidoidea
OR Aphis rapae var. laevigata - Riley 1875 (Aphidoidea): [Description,
   Original description, p. 202; Nomen dubium, P. 203]. 
   Macrosiphum euphorbiae - (Thomas 1878) (Aphidoidea): [Syn nov,
   Siphonophora fragariae var. immaculata Riley 1875, p. 201; Nomen
   protectum, P. 201]. 
   Myzus persicae - (Sulzer 1776) (Aphidoidea): [Syn nov, Aphis rapae var.
   laevigata Riley 1875, p. 202]. 
   Siphonophora fragariae var. immaculata - Riley 1875 (Aphidoidea):
   [Description, Original description, p. 202; Nomen oblitum, P. 201]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14709067279
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14609058043
DT Article
TI New archisargids from China (Insecta: Diptera).
AU Zhang, Kuiyan
   Yang, Ding (dyangcau@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Ren, Dong
   Shih, Chungkun
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 1
PS 75-80
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The extinct family Archisargidae, which was rich in the Mesozoic, has
   been found in China, Kazakhstan and Mongolia. By now, six genera and 14
   species have been found in Inner Mongolia and Liaoning Province of
   China. In this paper, two new species of the genus Mesosolva Hong, 1983
   and a new genus Brevisolva gen. nov., represented by a new species
   belonging to the Archisargidae, are described from the Middle Jurassic
   deposits of Daohugou, Inner Mongolia. A key to the species of Mesosolva
   is given.
C1 Yang, Ding; China Agr Univ, Dept Entomol, Beijing, China, China.
EM dyangcau@yahoo.com.cn

   Mongol /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ].

   Archisargidae, Type species Brevisolva daohugouensis Zhang, Ren & Shih

TI Mites of the genus Holostaspella (Acari: Gamasida: Macrochelidae) in
   Indonesia.
AU Hartini, Sri (hrtin2001@yahoo.com) 
   Takaku, Gen
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 1
PS 107-115
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The genus Holostaspella of the family Macrochelidae consists of more
   than 30 species. Of these, seven species have been recorded from
   Indonesia. In the present study, we review the genus in Indonesia,
   record two species (H. pulchella and H. similiornata) for the first time
   from Indonesia, and describe two new species (H. oblonga n. sp. and H.
   villosa n. sp.) on the basis of the specimens collected in Java and
   Sulawesi. A key to the species of the genus in Indonesia is also
   provided.

AB Adult and immature stages of a new whitefly species Dialeurodes swidi Ko
   are described and illustrated. It can be distinguished from other
   species by the abundant large tubercles scattered over its dorsum, each
   of them bearing a geminate pore. The biology, comparative notes and

DT Article
TI Pteromalid parasitoids (Hymenoptera) of Oulema oryzae (Kuwayama)
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae) from Japan, with notes on Pteromalus
   bifoveolatus.
AU Ishizaki, Tsuyoshi (tsuyoshiishizaki8@hotmail.com) 
   Ishikawa, Tadashi
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 1
PS 144-149
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 2
U2 3
AB The present paper discusses three Japanese species of Pteromalidae
   reared from cocoons of the rice beetle Oulema oryzae (Kuwayama, 1929)
   (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae). Pteromalus cyclostomus Ishizaki sp. nov. is
   described. Spaniopus monospilus (Thomson, 1878) and Usubaia liparae
   Kamijo, 1983 are newly recognized as parasitoid wasps of O. oryzae, and
   the former is also recorded from Japan for the first time. Pteromalus
   bifoveolatus Forster, 1861 is also newly recorded from Japan, with a new
   host record from Samia cynthia pryeri (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
C1 Ishizaki, Tsuyoshi; Tokyo Univ Agr, Entomol Lab, Atsugi, Kanagawa,
   Japan, Japan.

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

TI New Brazilian species of Endecous Saussure, 1878: Phallic sclerites,
   calling song and tegmen morphometry (Orthoptera: Grylloidea:
   Phalangopsinae).
AU Zefa, Edison (edzefa@gmail.com) 
   Mesa, Alejo
   Martins, Luciano de P.
SO Entomological Science
VL 13
IS 1
PS 150-155
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB In this paper we describe the phalangopsid cricket Endecous alejomesai
   n. sp. collected from the cave "Lapa do Fuzil", Vila Propicio, State of
   Goias, Brazil. Diagnosis has been acquired by the combination of the
   following characteristics: phallic sclerite features; calling song with
   dominant frequency of 4.8 kHz and 52.9 [plus or minus] 5.8 (42-60, n =
   22) cycles of sound per pulse; pars stridens with 90 [plus or minus]
   6.84 (78-99, n = 12) teeth; mirror with one or two cross-veins; harp
   with two, three or four cross-veins.
C1 Zefa, Edison; UFPel, Dept Zool & Genet, Capao Do Leao, RS, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM edzefa@gmail.com

TI GORGYRA STEWARTI SP NOV - A SURPRISING NEW SKIPPER BUTTERFLY FROM
   CAMEROUN AND THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (LEP.: HESPERIIDAE).
AU Larsen, Torben B. (torbenlarsen@btinternet.com) 
SO Entomologist's Record and Journal of Variation
VL 122
IS 2
PS 55-58
PD Mar 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB As part of preparatory work for a monograph on the skipper butterflies
   (Hesperiidae) of the Afrotropical Region a remarkably distinctive new
   species from Cameroun and the Democratic Republic of Congo was
   discovered and is here described as Gorgyra stewarti sp.nov. Its closest
   relative is Gorgyra subflavidus Holland, 1896 from the coastal forests
   of East Africa (Kenya and Tanzania), a distinct biogeographical
   subregion.

   Tavakilian, Gerard-Luc

VL 66
